{{Orphan|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox writer | name = Paco Ahlgren | image = Paco Ahlgren in 2008.jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1968|11|19}} | birth_place = [[El Paso, Texas]] | occupation = musician, author, journalist | genre = | movement = | website = {{URL|PacoAhlgren.com}} | awards = [[Next Generation Indie Book Awards|Next Generation Indie Book Award]]{{cite web| last=2008 Next Generation Indie Book Award |first= |title=Discipline - by Paco Ahlgren |work= Next Generation Indie Book Awards Website |accessdate= 2010-01-01 |url= http://www.indiebookawards.com/2008_winners_and_finalists.php|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014204536/http://www.indiebookawards.com/2008_winners_and_finalists.php|archivedate=2008-10-14}}
[[Foreword INDIES|INDIEFAB Book of the Year Award]], Silver{{cite web |title=2007 Foreword INDIES Winners in Science Fiction & Fantasy (Adult Fiction) |url=https://www.forewordreviews.com/awards/winners/2007/science-fiction-and-fantasy/ |publisher=[[Foreword Reviews]] |accessdate=30 October 2018 |language=en}} }} '''Paco Ahlgren''' (born '''Frank Richard Ahlgren, III''' on November 19, 1968) is an [[United States|American]] writer, musician, and financial journalist. His novel, ''Discipline'', was published in July 2007 by [[Greenleaf Book Group]]; it went on to receive three awards for commercial fiction.{{cite web| last=2008 Eric Hoffer Award |first= |title=Discipline - by Paco Ahlgren |work= Hoffer Award Website |accessdate= 2010-01-01 |url= http://www.hofferaward.com/Hofferaward.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151105112618/http://www.hofferaward.com/Eric-Hoffer-Award-winners.html|archivedate=2015-11-05}} == Work == Ahlgren began his musical career in 1987 as a teenager in [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama]], playing shows with his band The Bentley Tock.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1817&dat=19891026&id=3DkdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5qUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2719,7398410&hl=en|title=Unknown local band on verge of breakthrough|last=Cobb|first=Mark Hughes|date=October 26, 1989|work=The Tuscaloosa News|accessdate=14 July 2016}} The band's first single, ''She'', was the most requested song on [[WVUA-FM]] in 1988. In 1989, they played a well-received show at the [[University of Alabama]]'s Riverside Amphitheater and recorded a 6-song [[Extended Play|EP]], and then a full-length album in 1992 entitled ''Able''.{{cite web|url=http://www.tagtuner.com/music/albums/Bentley-Tock/Able/album-v2114c8c|title=Bentley Tock - Able|work=tagturner.com|accessdate=14 July 2016}} Ahlgren's novel, ''Discipline'', received a favorable review from [[Jeffrey Satinover]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1131&dat=20061004&id=4foyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gQ8GAAAAIBAJ&pg=695,3640420&hl=en|title=Novelist Ahlgren to teach thrill writing|date=October 5, 2007|work=Sedona Red Rock News|page=6B|accessdate=12 July 2016}} Discipline also received recommendations from ''The Midwest Book Review'',{{cite web| last=Cox |first=James A. |title=The Fiction Shelf |work= Midwest Book Review: Library Bookwatch, Volume 2, Number 9 |accessdate= 2008-01-18 |url= http://www.midwestbookreview.com/lbw/sep_07.htm}} ''[[The Houston Press]]''{{cite web| last=Ramey |first=Julia |title=Paco Ahlgren: Debut novelist reads from Discipline |work= Houston Press Arts and Entertainment |accessdate= 2008-01-18 |url= http://www.houstonpress.com/2007-08-23/calendar/paco-ahlgren/full}} and the ''[[Durango Herald]]''.{{cite web |last= Miller |first= Patricia |title= Supernatural crime fighting fills first novel |work= The Durango Herald |accessdate= 2008-01-18 |url= http://www.durangoherald.com/asp-bin/article_generation.asp?article_type=ae&article_path=/arts_entertainment/ae070706_2.htm |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070808063314/http://www.durangoherald.com/asp-bin/article_generation.asp?article_type=ae&article_path=%2Farts_entertainment%2Fae070706_2.htm |archivedate= 2007-08-08 |deadurl= yes |df= }} It was selected as a 2007 Booksense Notable by the [[American Booksellers Association]].{{cite web| last=2007 Booksense Notable |first= |title=Discipline - by Paco Ahlgren |work= Booksense Notable Website |accessdate= 2016-07-11 |url= http://www.bookweb.org/news/july-2007-book-sense-picks-notables-preview}} In 2009, it was optioned to become a motion picture, by [[David Permut]] and Steve Jones.{{cite news| last=McNary |first=James |title=Permut, Jones set 'Discipline' |work= Variety Magazine |accessdate= 2009-07-19 |url= http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118006172?refCatId=13 |date=2009-07-19}} Ahlgren is a contributing writer to [[Seeking Alpha]].{{cite web| last=Seeking Alpha |first= |title=Author, Paco Ahlgren |work= Seeking Alpha Website |accessdate= 2010-01-01 |url= http://seekingalpha.com/author/paco-ahlgren}} == Family == Ahlgren is the grandson of Frank Ahlgren Sr., editor of Memphis daily newspaper ''[[The Commercial Appeal]]'' for 32 years, and a [[University of Tennessee]] Board of Trustees member for 27 years. Ahlgren Sr. was involved in developing the university's School of Journalism in 1957, and was inducted into the ''Tennessee Newspaper Hall of Fame'' in November 2007.{{cite web| last=Tennessee Press Association |first= |title=Tennessee Newspaper Hall of Fame |work= tnpress.com |accessdate= 2016-07-12 |url= http://www.tnpress.com/halloffame.html}} == References == {{reflist|2}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ahlgren, Paco}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from El Paso, Texas]] [[Category:People from Austin, Texas]] [[Category:People from Durango, Colorado]] [[Category:American male novelists]] [[Category:Writers from Austin, Texas]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:Novelists from Texas]]

{{Use British English|date=December 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Spanish name|'''Bermúdez'''|'''Pippa'''}}
'''José Armando Bermúdez Pippa''' (12 November 1928 – 3 December 2014), known as '''Poppy Bermúdez''', was an [[Argentine]]-born [[People of the Dominican Republic|Dominican]] businessman and the third [[CEO]] of [[Bermúdez (rum)|J. Armando Bermúdez & Co., C. por A.]] after [[José Armando Bermúdez|José Armando]] and [[Domingo Octavio Bermúdez]].<ref name=Espinal>{{cite news|last1=Espinal|first1=Edwin|title=Los apellidos del ron: Bermúdez|url=http://hoy.com.do/capsulas-genealogicaslos-apellidos-del-ron-bermudez|accessdate=4 December 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141204054019/http://hoy.com.do/capsulas-genealogicaslos-apellidos-del-ron-bermudez|archivedate=4 December 2014|work=Cápsulas Genealógicas|agency=Instituto Dominicano de Genealogía|publisher=Hoy|date=29 August 2009|language=Spanish}}</ref>
==Biography== Born in [[Buenos Aires]] in 1928,<ref>''Puerto Rico, Passenger and Crew Lists, 1901-1962''</ref> he was the son of the Dominican businessman Aquiles Bermúdez Ramos (1901-1970) — the son of [[José Armando Bermúdez|José Armando Bermúdez Rochet]] and Ana Luisa Ramos de Peña — and Pastora Luisa Pippa, an [[Italian Argentine]] woman. A few months after he was born, his family moved to [[Santiago de los Caballeros]], Dominican Republic, where he lived the rest of his life.<ref name=Sol-Santiago>{{cite web|last1=Toribio|first1=Kilvin|title=Biografía de José Armando Bermúdez|url=http://elsoldesantiago.com/2014/12/biografia-de-jose-armando-bermudez-poppy|publisher=El Sol de Santiago|accessdate=4 December 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141204054005/http://elsoldesantiago.com/2014/12/biografia-de-jose-armando-bermudez-poppy/|archivedate=4 December 2014|location=Santiago de los Caballeros|language=Spanish|date=3 December 2014}}</ref>
In 1968, Bermúdez founded ''[[Color Visión]]'' the first [[color television]] [[Television channel|channel]] in the Dominican Republic and the third in [[Latin America]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Causa pesar muerte de Poppy Bermúdez|url=http://www.elcaribe.com.do/2014/12/04/causa-pesar-muerte-poppy-bermudez|accessdate=8 December 2014|publisher=El Caribe|date=4 December 2014|location=Santiago|language=Spanish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141208092524/http://www.elcaribe.com.do/2014/12/04/causa-pesar-muerte-poppy-bermudez|archivedate=8 December 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Death== Poppy Bermúdez died on 3 December 2014 in [[Santiago de los Caballeros]].
==Notes== {{Reflist}}

page.title: Public bicycle rental service in South Korea

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=July 2016}}
{{Infobox Korean name | title = '''Public bicycle rental service''' | image = File:페달로.jpg | caption = Public bicycle rental service in Ansan | hangul = {{linktext|무인| 자전거| 대여| 시스템}} | hanja = {{linktext|無人| 自轉車| 貸與}} 시스템 | rr = Muin jajeongeo daeyeo shiseutem | mr = Muin chachŏnkŏ taeyŏ sisŭte*m }}
'''[[Bicycle-sharing system|Public bicycle rental]] services''' are available in several cities across [[South Korea]], each managed by their respective [[Cities of South Korea|city governments]]. Bicycles can be used and paid for through an existing [[T-money|transportation card system]] or by [[mobile phone]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Seoul Bike Manger|title=Outline Of Bicycle Rental System|url=https://www.bikeseoul.com/info/infoResume.do|website=Seoul Bike|accessdate=2016-05-18}}</ref>
== Locations == [[File:페달로 자전거.jpg|thumb|A bicycle available for rent]] {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! class="unsortable" | Nat. ! Region ! Name |- | {{flagicon|South Korea}} | [[Ansan]] | Pedalro System (페달로) |- | {{flagicon|South Korea}} | [[Seoul]] | [[Ddareungi]] (따릉이) |- | {{flagicon|South Korea}} | [[Goyang]] | Fifteen (피프틴) |- | {{flagicon|South Korea}} | [[Yeosu]] | U - Bike (유 바이크) |- | {{flagicon|South Korea}} | [[Changwon]] | | Nubija (누비자) |- | {{flagicon|South Korea}} | [[Daejeon]] | Tashu System (타슈) |- | {{flagicon|South Korea}} | [[Suwon]] | Bandicle (반디클) |- | {{flagicon|South Korea}} | [[Danyang County|Danyang]] | Tabore (타보레) |}
== Usage == [[File:페달로 대여장치.jpg|thumb|Bicycle rental equipment]] [[File:페달로 키오스크.jpg|thumb|A bicycle rental kiosk]] [[File:페달로 키오스크 2.jpg|thumb|Screen of bicycle rental kiosk]] Any member of the public is able to use the system by either becoming a subscribing member or paying a one-off fee.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bikeseoul.com/app/use/moveUseMenuClauseInfo.do|title=서울자전거 이용약관|website=서울자전거 이용약관|publisher=서울자전거(따릉이)|trans-title=Terms & Conditions about seoul bike rental system|publication-date=2015-12-16|accessdate=2016-05-18}}</ref>
System setups differ between cities. In some areas, users must purchase a special card in order to hire a bicycle. Once registered for membership, users are able to use the system for free. There are various types of membership, which are defined by length of time and location. However, bicycles are not required to be returned to the same hire stand from which they were removed. Rental facilities are located at many sites around South Korea where users can rent and return bikes. Members are also able to view their ride details on the system's website.
== Typical features == Many South Korean localities manage their own public bicycle rental system. Each city's local government administers the program, resulting in some differences between jurisdictions.<ref>{{cite news|last1=온라인뉴스팀|title=서울 공공자전거 '따릉이'15일부터 운영…이용방법‘스마트폰 앱 대여’|url=http://www.sportsworldi.com/content/html/2015/10/15/20151015000765.html?OutUrl=naver|accessdate=2015-10-15|work=2016-06-22}}</ref>
== Coverage ==
=== Seoul === The city government in Seoul manages its own public bicycle rental system. 25 public bicycle rental stations in [[Yeouido]] and 18 stations in [[Sangam-dong]] are also provided by the Seoul government. Stations co-locate bicycle rentals, seats, and kiosks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.semstory.com/338|title=서울자전거 사용법 및 스테이션 구성요소|website=삼성전기|publisher=SEM STORY|trans-title=The instruction of Seoul public bike rental system and its facilities|publication-date=2014-07-29|accessdate=2016-05-18}}</ref>
=== Goyang === The Goyang city government manages its own public bicycle rental system named 'Fifteen' with 125 stations located across the metropolitan area. Users can either pay by credit card for one-off usage or purchase a membership card <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fifteenlife.com/introduce/ecobike_bike2.jsp|title=고양시 공공자전거 피프틴 라ㅡ잎(Fifteen Life) 사용법|website=Fifteen Life official website|publisher=Fifteen Life|trans-title=Fifteen Life(bike rental system in Goyang city) official website|publication-date=|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref>
=== Ansan === In Ansan, the city government's system is called 'Pedalro' with 101 stations are located in the city. Users who are members can hire bicycles for free for up to two hours after which 1000 won (approximately US$1) is payable for every additional 30 minutes. Yearly membership is 30,000 won (approximately US$28.17), a half year membership is 20,000 won (approximately US$18.78), monthly membership is 4,000 won (approximately US$3.76) and daily membership is 1,000 won (approximately US$1). [[Cycling]] in this city is very popular due to its ease of use in crowded urban areas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bike.moneyweek.co.kr/articleView.html?no=2013082212404503126|title=공공자전거 페달로··· 안산시민 쾌적한 발 '톡톡'|work=2016-06-20|publisher=Moneyweek|publication-date=2013-08-22|trans-title=Pedalro is being well received by Ansan citizen|last1=Park|first1=Jung-woong|accessdate=2013-08-22}}</ref> <ref>[https://www.pedalro.kr/info/aboutJoin.do?menuIdx=ab_02 안산시 공공자전거 가입안내]</ref>
=== Ulsan === The Ulsan city bicycle system has become very popular. Shortly after its launch, over five hundred residents and three hundred tourists used the system on a single day. As a result, the city's government has announced that the scheme will be expanded to accommodate the extra demand.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iusm.co.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=665215|title=중구 자전거대여소 인기…하루평균 500여명 이용|work=2016-06-20|publisher=울산매일 iusm.co.kr|publication-date=2016-06-02|trans-title=Bike rental system in Ul-san shows tremendous popularity|last1=조|first1=혜정|accessdate=2016-06-02}}</ref>
== Public reception == The success of bicycle share systems in existing cities has prompted other governments, such as [[Sejong City|Sejong]].,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kwan, Sunjae|title=세종시, 공공자전거 '어울링' 확대 운영...대중교통 연계도 강화|url=http://news.khan.co.kr/kh_news/khan_art_view.html?artid=201603281327051&code=620108|publisher=Kyunghyang News|trans-title=Sejong government expands public bike rental system|accessdate=2016-07-24|work=2016-03-28}}</ref> to consider introducing their own programs. Authorities in cities with existing systems have also announced expansion plans to cater for growing demand.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ok, Yujung|title=서울시, 공공자전거 '따릉이' 확대 설치|url=http://news.kbs.co.kr/news/view.do?ncd=3251239&ref=A|publisher=KBS|trans-title=Seoul government expands public bike rental system|accessdate=2016-07-24|work=2016-03-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Lee, Jonghoon|title=고양 공공임대자전거 서비스 확대|url=http://www.incheonilbo.com/?mod=news&act=articleView&idxno=700328|publisher=Incheonilbo|trans-title=Goyang government expands public bike rental service|accessdate=2016-07-24|work=2016-03-30}}</ref>
Other businesses have been established to cater for the surge in popularity of bicycles, boosting local economies. These include companies supplying protective gear and custom-designed bicycles.<ref>{{cite news|last1=SBSCNBC|title=[터치&이슈] 대한민국 휩쓴 자전거 열풍…관련 산업도 '쑥쑥'|url=http://sbscnbc.sbs.co.kr/read.jsp?pmArticleId=10000768128|accessdate=2015-11-13|work=2016-06-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.mk.co.kr/newsRead.php?year=2013&no=523750|title=씽씽 달리는 자전거주…공공자전거 확대로 수요 급증|work=2016-06-20|publisher=매일경제 MBN|publication-date=2013-07-01|trans-title=Stock prices of bicycle industry are increasing with public bike system|last1=Kim|first1=Kab Ho|accessdate=2013-07-01}}</ref>
The environmental benefits of the system have been estimated at 25 trillion won, primarily from carbon emissions savings as a result of bicycle usage.<ref>{{cite news|last1=이|first1=슬기|title=University: "25 million won saved by cycling"|url=http://www.outdoornews.co.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=20132|accessdate=2015-11-13|work=2016-06-23}}</ref>
== Future development == A number of upgrades to the system have been announced, including the launch of a [[mobile app]] allowing users to rent & return system using [[smartphone]]s.<ref>{{cite news|last1=온라인뉴스팀|title=서울 공공자전거 '따릉이'15일부터 운영…이용방법‘스마트폰 앱 대여’|url=http://www.sportsworldi.com/content/html/2015/10/15/20151015000765.html?OutUrl=naver|accessdate=2015-10-15|work=2016-06-22}}</ref>

[http://tour.iansan.net/tour/guide/catalog/pedalro.pdf <nowiki>"안산시 페달로 지도"[A map of Pedalro - Ansan public bike rental service)]</nowiki>]. The Daegu borough of Dalseogu. * Shin, Heechul (2012-10-31). '''Reverse innovation''' or '''trickle-up innovation''' is an [[innovation]] seen or used first in the [[developing world]], before spreading to the industrialized world. The term was popularized by [[Dartmouth College|Dartmouth]] professors [[Vijay Govindarajan]] and [[Chris Trimble]] and GE's [[Jeffrey R. Immelt]].<ref name="EmoryMarketing">{{Cite web |title=How GE is Disrupting Itself. ''(Harvard Business Review)'' |url=http://files.gereports.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/hbr_how_ge_is_disrupting_itself.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110202104955/http://files.gereports.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/hbr_how_ge_is_disrupting_itself.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=21 October 2009 }}</ref><ref name="EmoryMarketing" /><ref>{{Cite web |title=Emory Marketing Institute Interview with Vijay Govindarajan |url=http://www.emorymi.com/reverseinnovation.shtml |accessdate=22 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091025050858/http://www.emorymi.com/reverseinnovation.shtml |archivedate=25 October 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=GE's Immelt Says 'Reverse Innovation' Needed for Global Growth ''(Bloomberg)'' |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601103&sid=aSCFSgKgjh1g |accessdate=21 October 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=The Case for 'Reverse Innovation' Now ''(BusinessWeek)'' |url=http://www.businessweek.com/innovate/content/oct2009/id20091026_724658.htm |accessdate=28 October 2009 }}</ref> Subsequently, Vijay Govindarajan and Chris Trimble published the book [http://innovationreverse.com/ ''Reverse Innovation''].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.innovationreverse.com/ | title=Reverse Innovation | People: VG}}</ref>
Reverse innovation is the process whereby goods developed as inexpensive models to meet the needs of developing nations, such as battery-operated medical instruments in countries with limited [[infrastructure]], are then repackaged as low-cost innovative goods for Western buyers.
== Definition == The process of reverse innovation begins by focusing on needs and requirements for low-cost products in countries like India. Once products are developed for these markets, they are then sold elsewhere - even in the West - at low prices which creates new markets and uses for these innovations.
Typically, companies start their globalization efforts by removing expensive features from their established product, and attempt to sell these de-featured products in the developing world. This approach, unfortunately, is not very competitive, and targets only the most affluent segments of society in these developing countries. Reverse innovation, on the other hand, leads to products which are created locally in developing countries, tested in local markets, and, if successful, then upgraded for sale and delivery in the developed world.
The term 'reverse innovation' was originally defined differently as - '''innovation blowback''' - by [[John Hagel III]] and [[John Seely Brown]] in their 2005 ''McKinsey Quarterly'' article titled ''Innovation blowback: Disruptive management practices from Asia.''<ref>{{Cite web|title=Innovation blowback: Disruptive management practices from Asia ''(McKinsey Quarterly)'' |url=http://www.johnseelybrown.com/innovationblowback.pdf |accessdate=1 January 2010 }}</ref> In essence, their message warns that "the periphery of today's global business environment is where innovation potential is the highest... Edges define and describe the borders of companies, markets, industries, geographies, intellectual disciplines, and generations. They are the places where unmet customer needs find unexpected solutions, where [[disruptive innovation]]s and blue oceans get birthed, and where edge capabilities transform the core competencies of the corporation." <ref>{{Cite web|title=Embrace the Edge -- or Perish ''(BusinessWeek)'' |url=http://www.businessweek.com/innovate/content/nov2007/id20071128_162890.htm |accessdate=1 January 2010 }}</ref>
[[C.K. Prahalad]]<ref>{{Cite web|title=5 Tips for Trickle-Up Innovation from C.K. Prahalad ''(BusinessWeek)'' |url=http://www.businessweek.com/innovate/next/archives/2009/04/5_tips_for_tric.html |accessdate=22 October 2009 }}</ref> explains that there are five ways in which resource-starved developing countries lead rich nations: 1) affordability, 2) leapfrog technologies, 3) service ecosystems, 4) robust systems, and 5) add-on applications. These very deprivations are catalysts for reverse innovation.
== Reverse innovation in global health systems ==
Reverse innovation has been identified as a key emerging trend in global health systems.<ref>{{cite news|last=Carus|first=Felicity|title=Reverse innovation brings social solutions to developed countries|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/reverse-innovation-social-solutions-home|accessdate=30 January 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=29 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Belluz|first=Julia|title=7 key health trends for 2013|url=http://www2.macleans.ca/2012/12/27/seven-key-health-trends-for-2013/|accessdate=30 January 2013|newspaper=Maclean's|date=December 27, 2012}}</ref> Key health areas where low-income countries can offer solutions to medium and high-income country settings include, rural health service delivery; skills substitution; decentralisation of management; creative problem-solving; education in communicable disease control; innovation in mobile phone use; low technology simulation training; local product manufacture; health financing; and social entrepreneurship.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Developed-developing country partnerships: Benefits to developed countries?|journal=Globalization and Health|volume=8|pages=17|url=http://www.globalizationandhealth.com/content/8/1/17|accessdate=30 January 2013|doi=10.1186/1744-8603-8-17|pmid=22709651|pmc=3459713|year=2012|last1=Syed|first1=Shamsuzzoha B.|last2=Dadwal|first2=Viva|last3=Rutter|first3=Paul|last4=Storr|first4=Julie|last5=Hightower|first5=Joyce D.|last6=Gooden|first6=Rachel|last7=Carlet|first7=Jean|last8=Nejad|first8=Sepideh|last9=Kelley|first9=Edward T.|last10=Donaldson|first10=Liam|last11=Pittet|first11=Didier}}</ref> System-wide benefits may also be seen as accruing across every part of the World Health Organization Health Systems Framework, specifically the six building blocks of health systems: (1) service delivery; (2) health workforce; (3) health information; (4) medical products, vaccines, and technologies; (5) health financing; and (6) health leadership and governance. However, the applicability of developing country innovations in developed country settings remains relatively undocumented and further work needs to be undertaken to advance understanding of health innovation diffusion between countries.<ref>{{cite web|title=http://blogs.biomedcentral.com/bmcblog/2012/10/09/reverse-innovation-in-global-health-systems-call-for-papers/|url=http://blogs.biomedcentral.com/bmcblog/2012/10/09/reverse-innovation-in-global-health-systems-call-for-papers/|publisher=BioMed Central Blog|accessdate=30 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208022235/http://blogs.biomedcentral.com/bmcblog/2012/10/09/reverse-innovation-in-global-health-systems-call-for-papers/|archivedate=8 February 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Other examples==
Examples of reverse innovation can be found across various industries and geographies:<ref>{{Cite web|title=How Innovations from Developing Nations Trickle-Up to the West ''(Fast Company)'' |url=http://www.fastcompany.com/magazine/133/as-the-world-turns.html |accessdate=22 October 2009 |date=March 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Innovation Trickles in a New Direction ''(BusinessWeek)'' |url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/09_12/b4124038287365.htm |accessdate=22 October 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Microsoft bets on making "dumb" phones smarter ''(BusinessWeek)'' |url=http://www.businessweek.com/innovate/next/archives/2009/08/microsoft_bets.html |accessdate=22 October 2009 }}</ref>
- '''Nokia''' is testing new business models for classified ads in Kenya; it has also created new features in its hand-held phones sold in the US, based on observations of how phones are shared in Ghana.
- '''Microsoft''' is creating new phone app services for "dumb" phones which allow users with existing, non-smartphone devices to access Web sites such as Twitter, Facebook. Built for markets in India and South Africa, there is surprising potential for these apps as a low-cost cloud computing platform.
- '''GE''' is now selling an ultra-portable electrocardiograph machine in the U.S. at an 80% markdown for similar products. The machine was originally built by GE Healthcare for doctors in India and China.
- '''Tata Motors''' is planning to sell an upgraded version of the [[Tata Nano]] in western markets; it's called '''Tata Europa'''.
- '''Procter & Gamble''' found that a honey-based cold remedy created for Mexico also had a profitable market in Europe and the United States.
- '''Nestlé''' learned that it could sell its low-cost, low-fat dried noodles originally created for rural India and position the same product as a healthy alternative in Australia and New Zealand.
Reverse innovations may or may not be [[disruptive innovation|disruptive innovations]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Is Reverse Innovation Like Disruptive Innovation? ''(Harvard Business Review Voices)'' |url=http://blogs.harvardbusiness.org/hbr/hbr-now/2009/09/is-reverse-innovation-like-dis.html |accessdate=21 October 2009 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}}

{{BLP sources|date=April 2011}} [[File:Ricardo Belmont 3.jpg|thumb|Ricardo Belmont Cassinelli]] '''Ricardo Belmont Cassinelli''' is a [[Peru]]vian [[TV network]] owner and politician. He was the mayor of [[Lima]]<ref name="FoxFox1997">{{cite book|last1=Fox|first1=Elizabeth|last2=Fox|first2=Fox de Cardona|title=Latin American broadcasting: from tango to telenovela|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9g63lxssFP8C&pg=PA87|accessdate=7 April 2011|year=1997|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=978-1-86020-515-6|page=87}}</ref> from 1990 to 1995. He was popularly known as "El Hermanón" (Big Brother) for his friendliness and also as "El Colora'o" (Ginger) because of his reddish hair.
==Career== Ricardo Belmont is the son of Augusto Belmont Bar, who founded TV Bego Excelsior (Channel 11 in Peru) in 1967. TV Bego Excelsior also owned Excelsior FM radio (104.7 FM in Peru). The younger Belmont was an avid sportsman who enjoyed [[soccer]] and [[boxing]], and was a patron of players in both sports. His sports passion would later influence him in his political speeches, using sporting terms such as "let's all kick into the same goal post", and, during his reelection bid, "Second half time is about to start, and it's works vs. words. Choose the tree [his electoral [[symbol]]] and we'll win the game." In his "serious" life, he dedicated himself to [[journalism]], befriending several local and national politicians all the while aspiring to be his own man in the media business. In his spare time he also dedicated his life to worthy causes, the most prominent being the local '''Telethon''' (based on the American version by [[Jerry Lewis]]), dedicated to helping the disabled kids at the San Juan de Dios Clinic in Lima.
In 1986 he took over Channel 11 and renamed it Red Bicolor de Comunicaciones (''Bicolor Communications Network''; the initials RBC allude to his personal name). Initially airing only from noon to midnight, Belmont mostly purchased American programming such as [[Bonanza]], [[Get Smart]], [[Bravestarr]], and [[The Twilight Zone]] (the 1985 version). The few RBC-produced shows included "Desafio Familiar", which was a Peruvian version of [[Family Feud]], "Habla el Pueblo", a [[Larry King]]-inspired talk show with Belmont himself as host, and "Mirando la Música", a [[music video]] program. In the late 1980s RBC started diversifying to break out of the niche market to compete with the Peruvian Big Two, America Television and Panamericana Television. RBC Radio 980 AM was mostly sports talk, while 91.9 FM was adult contemporary, in addition to Excelsior, which was mostly tropical and salsa.
In 1990 he announced his candidacy for the Lima provincial mayoralty as an independent. His political party, OBRAS (Works) alluded to the need for public works in Lima and the overall lack of progress as mayor by [[Jorge del Castillo Gálvez]], who was seen more as a lackey of Peruvian President [[Alan García]] than as an effective mayor. Although he supported [[Mario Vargas Llosa]]'s Presidential candidacy, he chose to oppose Vargas Llosa's party's chosen mayoral candidate, [[Juan Inchaustegui]]. Belmont's charisma developed as a TV host and his lack of political affiliation helped him earn the people's vote, and he began to start his public-works program, which included several road and community improvement projects detailed below.
Initially Belmont and the new Peruvian president, [[Alberto Fujimori]], were seen as comrades in arms because of their common political backgrounds as independents. The fiercely independent Belmont, however, drawing on his business skills, was able to get funds from several private enterprises to fund his programs.
Among the many public works projects he completed include: *Intercambio Vial Norte (Northern Interchange): was a paving of Avenida Universitaria linking Carabayllo and San Miguel districts, with an interchange with Panamericana Norte along the way. *Intercambio Vial Este (Eastern Interchange): was a combination of two new bridges spanning the Rimac River linking El Agustino directly with San Juan de Lurigancho *Intercambio Vial Sur (Southern Interchange): was an actual [[Interchange (road)|interchange]] between Panamericana Sur, Av. Circunvalacion and Av. Javier Prado that eliminated traffic light crossings. *Several ''losa deportiva''s (sports grounds) for poor communities, mostly [[concrete]] fields for mini-soccer, basketball, and squash.
Elected to a second term in 1994, Belmont and Fujimori had a falling out, due to resentment from Fujimori at Belmont's former support of Vargas Llosa. Fujimori, through his party-controlled Congress, issued Legislative Decree No. 776, by which provincial mayors were forced to distribute their government income down to the distrital halls under them (particularly from rich to poor distrital municipalities in the interior of the country). This stopped Belmont from pursuing further public works and improvements, and the municipal employees (most of whom were APRA party members left over from the Castillo administration) began turning against him through demonstrations, increasing his unpopularity.

{{BLP sources|date=January 2009}} {{Infobox Officeholder | name = Sani Bello | image = | imagesize = | smallimage = | caption = | order = | office =[[List of Governors of Kano State|Governor]], [[Kano State]], [[Nigeria]] [[File:Seal of Kano.png|thumb|Seal of the Governor of the State of Kano]] | term_start =July 1975 | term_end =Sept 1978 | predecessor =Comm. of Police [[Audu Bako]] | successor =Group Captain [[Ishaya Aboi Shekari]] | party = None ( retired military officer) | birth_date ={{Birth date and age|1942|11|27|df=y}} | birth_place =[[Kontagora]], [[Niger State]], [[Nigeria]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality =[[Nigerian]] | spouse = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = Telecom/ Electricity Investor | profession = | religion =islam | website = | footnotes = |allegiance = {{flag|Nigeria}} |branch =<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Nigerian Army crest.gif|23px]] -->''[[Nigerian Army]]'' |rank = [[Colonel]] }} [[image:NigeriaKano.png|thumb|right|200px|[[Kano State]] in [[Nigeria]]]]
'''Sani Bello''' (born 27 November 1942) is a [[Nigeria]]n businessman and retired [[Military of Nigeria|Nigerian Army]] [[colonel]] and founder of the Sani Bello Foundation.<ref>Boboye Onduku.(2012) Investors Must Learn to Be Patient. Leadership (Abuja) November 27, 2012</ref>
==Early life and education== Sani Bello was born in 1942 at [[Kontagora]], [[Niger State]], the only child of Bello Mustapha and Hajiya Abu. He attended Central Primary School, Kotangora in 1950 and Government College, Bida {Niger State} in 1957, before joining the Nigerian Army in December 1962 as an officer [[Cadet]] at the Nigerian Military Training College, Kaduna. He attended [[Royal Military Academy Sandhurst]] in England and graduated as a [[Second Lieutenant|2nd Lieutenant]] in July 1965.
==Career== Following [[Officer (armed forces)|commission]] he returned to Nigeria and was posted to 1st Battalion, [[Enugu]] as a [[Platoon|Platoon Commander]]. He then held various posts in the Army as he progressed in ranks, including ADC to Major General [[Johnson Aguiyi-Ironsi]], Nigeria’s first military head of state. During the [[Nigerian Civil War]], he was a training officer at the 6th Battalion, Ikeja before he was posted to [[Kingdom of Bonny|Bonny]] as the Sector Commander.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sani Bello An Exceptional Entrepreneur|url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Nigeria_federal_states.htm|work=Timothy Opaluwa|publisher=Leadership, Nigeria|date=5 December 2015}}</ref> During the war, Bello was wounded at Bonny and evacuated to Lagos for treatment, in Lagos, he served as a staff officer at the Lagos Garrison division. He was later posted to various commands including serving as Commander of the Oshodi Resettlement Center and Rear Commander of defunct Third Marine Commando division. He was also General Staff Officer and Assistant Quartermaster General of the 3rd Division. From 1971 to 1974, he was Deputy Adjutant General of the Nigerian army before becoming the Commanding Officer of the 81 Battalion, Kaduna. He retired from the Nigerian army as a Principal Staff Officer.
===Military Administrator of Kano=== Sani Bello was also a Military Governor of the old [[Kano State]] from 1975 – 1978.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nigeria States|url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Nigeria_federal_states.htm|work=Ben Cahoon|publisher=worldstatesmen.org|date=11 November 2010}}</ref> During his tenure, he focused on commerce, rural roads, electrification and primary and secondary education. In 1976, he developed a Science Secondary School Management Board establishing science colleges to train Kano State residents and give them the opportunity to qualify for science courses at the university level also to climb to middle and top level grades in the government.<ref>Danyaro, M. M. (1998). Kano State: 30 years of statehood. Kano State, Nigeria: publisher not identified.</ref> Notable schools established during the period are Dawakin Kudu and Dawakin Tofa Science schools. His administration was also tasked to implement two key Federal programmes: local government reform and universal primary education. Local government reform led to the creation of 20 [[Local government areas of Nigeria|local government areas]] in Kano.
Alfa Wali, Balarabe Ismail were SMGs in the administration, Abdu Sambo and [[Abdullahi Aliyu Sumaila]] served as the scribes (Secretary to the Executive Council) to his government.Umaru Abdulwahab was the Principal Secretary to the Governor
===Business career=== After retirement in 1979, Colonel Bello held various part-time appointments as a chairman of Niger State Green Revolution, Niger State NYSC, Niger State Polytechnic and Niger State Science and Technical School Board. He also served as Nigerian [[High Commissioner]] (Ambassador) to Zimbabwe from 1984- 1986.
On his return home from Zimbabwe Bello became involved with various companies as chairman or director, including former Broadbank Nigeria Ltd, Globe Re Nigeria Ltd, Law Union and [[Skye Bank|Rock Insurance Company Plc]], Dantata and Sawoe Construction Company Ltd, [[MTN Group|MTN Communications Ltd]], Equatel Communication Ltd, President of National Association of Indigenous Petroleum Explorers in Nigeria and Mainstream Energy Solutions ltd Nigeria. He is also a farmer and Proprietor of [[Mustafa]] Comprehensive School, [[Kontagora]]. He is a co-founder of Amni International Petroleum Development Company Ltd that has interest in Ketu and Okoro oilfields.
He is a passionate lover of sports, especially table tennis in which he once served as the Chairman of Nigerian Table Tennis Federation and led the national team to the [[Commonwealth]] and World Championships in 1983.

[[File:Schneider Trophy Science Museum London.jpg|thumb|The Schneider Trophy, on display at the [[Science Museum, London]]]] The '''Coupe d<nowiki>'</nowiki>Aviation Maritime Jacques Schneider''', commonly called the '''Schneider Trophy''' or '''Schneider Prize''' (sometimes incorrectly referred to as the ''Schneider Cup'', a different prize), was a trophy awarded annually (and later, biennially) to the winner of a race for [[seaplane]]s and flying boats. The Schneider Trophy is now held at the Science Museum, South Kensington, London.
Announced in 1912 by [[Jacques Schneider]], a French financier, balloonist and aircraft enthusiast, the competition offered a prize of approximately £1,000. The race was held twelve times between 1913 and 1931. It was intended to encourage technical advances in civil aviation but became a contest for pure speed with laps over a (usually) triangular course (initially 280 km, later 350 km). The contests were staged as time trials, with aircraft setting off individually at pre-agreed times, usually 15 minutes apart. The contests were very popular and some attracted crowds of over 200,000 spectators. An earlier trophy, also presented by Jacques Schneider in 1910, in France, was the Schneider Cup, which is now in the possession of the [[RAF College Cranwell]].
If an aero club won three races in five years, they would retain the trophy and the winning pilot would receive 75,000 [[franc]]s for each of the first three wins. Each race was hosted by the previous winning country. The races were supervised by the [[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]] and the aero club in the hosting country. Each club could enter up to three competitors with an equal number of alternatives.
The race was significant in advancing aeroplane design, particularly in the fields of [[aerodynamics]] and engine design, and would show its results in the best fighters of World War II. The streamlined shape and the low drag, liquid-cooled engine pioneered by Schneider Trophy designs are obvious in the British [[Supermarine Spitfire]], the American [[North American P-51 Mustang]], and the Italian [[Macchi C.202|Macchi C.202 ''Folgore'']].
The Schneider Trophy is a sculpture of silver & bronze set on a marble base. It depicts a zephyr skimming the waves, and a nude winged figure is seen kissing a zephyr recumbent on a breaking wave. The heads of two other zephyrs and of [[Neptune (mythology)|Neptune]], the god of the Sea, can be seen surrounded by octopus and crabs. The symbolism represents speed conquering the elements of sea and air.
==History== The first competition was held on 16 April 1913, at [[Monaco]]. It was won by a French [[Société pour les Appareils Deperdussin|Deperdussin]] at an average speed of {{convert|73.56|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Eves240">Eves 2001, p. 240</ref>
The British won in 1914 with a [[Sopwith Tabloid]] at {{convert|139.74|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Eves240"/>
After [[World War I]], the competition resumed in 1919 at [[Bournemouth]] where in [[fog]]gy conditions the Italian team won. They were later disqualified and the race was voided.<ref name="Eves241">Eves 2001, p. 241</ref>
In 1920 and 1921 at [[Venice]] the Italians won — in 1920 no other nation entered and in 1921 the French entry did not start.<ref name="Eves241"/> After 1921, an additional requirement was added: the winning seaplane had to remain moored to a buoy for six hours without human intervention.
In 1922 in [[Naples]] the British and French competed with the Italians. The British private entry, a [[Supermarine Sea Lion II]], was the victor.<ref name="Eves242">Eves 2001, p. 242</ref> The French aircraft did not start the race, which became a competition between the Sea Lion and three Italian aircraft,<ref>[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1922/1922%20-%200495.html Schneider Victor's Welcome Home]</ref> including a [[Macchi M.7]] and a Savoia.
The 1923 trophy, contested at [[Cowes]], went to the Americans with a sleek, liquid-cooled engined craft designed by [[Glenn Curtiss]]. It used the [[Curtiss D-12]] engine. US Navy Lieutenant David Rittenhouse won the cup.<ref name="Eves242"/>
In 1924 there was no competition as no other nation turned out to face the Americans — the Italians and the French withdrew and both British craft crashed in pre-race trials.
In 1925 at [[Chesapeake Bay]] the Americans won again, the US pilot [[Jimmy Doolittle]] winning in a [[Curtiss R3C]] ahead of the British [[Gloster III]] and the Italian entry. Two British planes did not compete ([[R. J. Mitchell]]'s [[Supermarine S.4]] and the other Gloster III were damaged before the race). Two of the American planes did not finish.<ref name="Eves242"/>
In 1926, the Italians returned with a [[Macchi M.39]] and won against the Americans with a {{convert|396.69|km/h|abbr=on}} run at [[Hampton Roads]].<ref>Eves 2001, p. 243</ref>
In 1927 at Venice there was a strong British entry with government backing and [[Royal Air Force|RAF]] pilots (the [[High Speed Flight RAF|High Speed Flight]]) for [[Supermarine]], [[Gloster Aircraft Company|Gloster]], and [[Short Brothers|Shorts]]. Supermarine's Mitchell-designed S.5s took first and second places. 1927 was the last annual competition, the event then moving to a biennial schedule to allow for more development time.<ref name="Eves244">Eves 2001, p. 244</ref>
In 1929, at [[Calshot]], [[Supermarine]] won again in the [[Supermarine S.6]] with the new [[Rolls-Royce R]] engine with an average speed of {{convert|528.89|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Eves244"/> Both Britain and Italy entered two new aircraft and a backup plane from the previous race. <!-- {| class="wikitable sortable" |- |+ 1929 Race - Calshot |- ! In 1931 the British government withdrew support, but a private donation of £100,000 from [[Lucy, Lady Houston]], allowed Supermarine to compete and win on 13 September against only British opposition, with reportedly half a million spectators lining the beachfronts. The Italian, French, and German entrants failed to ready their aircraft in time for the competition. The remaining British team set both a new world speed record ({{convert|610|km/h|abbr=on}}) and won the trophy outright with a third straight win.<ref>Eves 2001, p. 245</ref> The following days saw the winning [[Supermarine S.6B]] further break the world speed record twice, making it the first craft to break the 400 mph barrier on 29 September at an average speed of {{convert|655.8|km/h|abbr=on}}.
Development of the other entrants did not cease there. The proposed Italian entrant (the [[Macchi M.C.72]]) which pulled out of the contest due to engine problems later went on to set two new world speed records. In April 1933 (over [[Lake Garda]], in northern Italy) it set a record with a speed of {{convert|682.36|km/h|abbr=on}}. Eighteen months later in the same venue, it broke the 700 km/h barrier with an average speed of {{convert|709.202|km/h|abbr=on}}. Both times the plane was piloted by [[Francesco Agello]]. This speed remains the fastest speed ever attained by a piston-engined seaplane.<ref name="Gunston58">Gunston 1989, p. 58</ref>.

==Alumni== *[[R. J. Mitchell|Reginald J. Mitchell]], designer of the winning Supermarine Schneider Trophy entrants, also designed the [[Supermarine Spitfire]]. *[[Mario Castoldi]], designer of the 1926 winner, the [[Macchi M.39]], also designed other contestants such as the M.52, the M.52R, the M.67, and the [[Macchi M.C.72|M.C.72]]. After the M.C.72 Castoldi designed some of the Italian fighters which flew during [[World War II]], such as the [[MC.202]]. *[[Jimmy Doolittle|James Doolittle]], winning pilot of the 1925 race, was accomplished in many other areas. He led the famous "[[Doolittle Raid]]", an American bombing attack on several Japanese homeland targets in April 1942.
The trophy itself has been entrusted to the [[Royal Aero Club]] and can be viewed along with the winning [[Supermarine S.6B]] floatplane at the [[Science Museum (London)|London Science Museum]] Flight exhibition hall. Supermarine S.6, ''N248'', which competed in the 1929 contest but was disqualified, is preserved at [[Solent Sky]] maritime museum in [[Southampton]].<ref>[http://www.spitfireonline.co.uk/ Solent Sky aviation museum]</ref>
==Revival in name== In 1981 the race was revived, in name if not in concept, by the [[Royal Aero Club]] of Great Britain to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Britain's ultimate retention of the Trophy. The original Trophy remained in the Science Museum, and a full-size replica was cast and the race opened on a handicapped basis to any propeller–driven landplane capable of maintaining 100 miles per hour in straight and level flight, and weighing up to 12,500 lb. Pilots also had to have a minimum of 100 hours as pilot-in-command, and a valid air racing licence.
Following that event, the UK subsidiary of US computer company [[Digital Equipment Corporation]] (DEC) independently decided to sponsor a long-term revival of the Schneider Trophy, with the first race held in 1984. The idea was submitted by DEC's then UK PR consultancy Infopress as part of a broader commercial sponsorship programme designed to increase DEC's presence in the UK market at that time. DEC sponsored this revived race series from 1984 until 1991, which also marked the diamond jubilee of the final race in the original series. DEC and Infopress turned to the expertise of the Royal Aero Club's Records, Racing & Rally Association which again administered and ran the actual races. The 1981 Solent course, itself a close approximation of the original 1929 and 1931 Schneider Trophy courses over the Solent, was also used and adapted from year to year.
This sponsorship had a profound effect on the awareness and popularity of handicapped air racing in the UK and further afield, as well as markedly increasing DEC's commercial profile in the UK. The appeal of the race, its historic connections, and the fact that prize money was now on offer, meant that the entry list for the race was large enough to warrant the introduction of heats from 1985 onwards. (The 1984 race field was 62 entrants, believed at the time to be the largest-ever in all forms of air racing.)
The event received further boosts in 1986, when it was started by HRH Prince Andrew and his then fiancée Sarah Ferguson; in 1987, when the event was featured as one episode in a BBC television documentary series; and in 1988, when it was a central part of that year's ITV Telethon Appeal.
DEC invited customers and partners to each year's event as guests, and the general public watched in increasing numbers as the series grew in size and popularity.
For the pilots taking part, the event became, along with the [[King's Cup Race]], the highlight of the UK's air racing season, and regularly attracted entrants from continental Europe.
DEC continued to sponsor the races through 1991. Since that time, the race has been run by the [http://www.britishairracing.com Royal Aero Club Records Racing and Rally Association] along with the King's Cup and the [[British air racing championship]]. The venue has varied but is still flown on most occasions around a Solent-based course, usually around September of each year.

==In popular culture== *The Schneider Cup is frequently referred to in the 1992 animated film ''[[Porco Rosso]]'', even to the extent of director [[Hayao Miyazaki]]'s naming the film's antagonist Donald Curtiss, a reference to American aircraft designers [[Glenn Curtiss]] and [[Donald Wills Douglas, Sr.|Donald Douglas]]. *In the song "Bill Hosie" by [[Archie Fisher]], the [[protagonist]] rebuilds a [[Supermarine S.5]] [[seaplane]] that survived the 1927 Schneider Trophy Race. The plane, race, and trophy are referred to throughout the song. (Bill Hosie and the replica were both real. Hosie competed in the 1985 and 1986 DEC Schneider Trophy Races, and DEC partly financed his rebuild of the S.5 replica. He crashed during a test-flight of this replica on 23 May 1987, near Mylor, in Cornwall in the UK,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caa.co.uk/docs/33/CAP673.PDF|title=Aviatrion safety review|date=May 1997|publisher=Civil Aviation Authority|page=17|accessdate=19 August 2011}}</ref> just one month before that year's DEC Schneider Trophy Race. Hosie was killed. Details of the crash and its cause are in AIB Bulletin 9/87 published by the [[Accidents Investigation Branch]] of the UK's [[Department for Transport|Department of Transport]], 1987.) *The film ''[[The First of the Few]]'' (1942) starring [[Leslie Howard (actor)|Leslie Howard]] as [[R. J. Mitchell]] centers on Mitchell's life as the designer of multiple Schneider Trophy–winning seaplanes and then the [[Supermarine Spitfire|Spitfire]] fighter plane.
