[[Los Angeles Kings]]
[[New York Rangers]]
[[Dallas Stars]] | ntl_team = CAN | draft = Undrafted | career_start = 2000 | career_end = 2012 }} '''Sean Christopher Avery''' (born April 10, 1980) is a Canadian former professional ice hockey player. During his career in the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL), he played left wing for the [[Detroit Red Wings]], [[Los Angeles Kings]], [[Dallas Stars]] and [[New York Rangers]], gaining recognition for his [[Pest (ice hockey)|agitating]] playing style and controversial behaviour both on and off the ice. He is also known for his eclectic interests, having worked in fashion, most notably as an intern at ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' magazine; as a model; and as a restaurateur. He finished his 12-year career with a total of 90 goals, 247 points and 1,533 penalty minutes in 580 games. After retiring in 2012, Avery began working at Lipman, an advertising and creative agency in New York City. He was promoted to senior staffer, but the firm closed without notice in September 2013, reportedly due to financial problems, later filing for bankruptcy, and owing Avery $229,167.{{Cite news|url = https://nypost.com/2013/10/23/sean-avery-owed-229k-by-bankrupt-lipman-agency/|title = Sean Avery owed $229K by bankrupt Lipman agency|last = Claire Atkinson|date = October 23, 2013|work = New York Post|access-date = October 6, 2015}} Avery's memoir, ''Ice Capades: A Memoir of Fast Living and Tough Hockey'', was published by [[Blue Rider Press]] in 2017. ==Early life== Avery was born in [[North York, Ontario]],{{Cite journal|url = http://torontolife.com/city/nhl-fans-break-from-playoffs-to-discuss-gay-marriage-because-apparently-its-still-2006/|title = NHL fans break from playoffs to discuss gay marriage—because, apparently, it’s still 2006|last = John Michael McGrath|date = May 10, 2011|journal = Toronto Life|access-date = October 6, 2015}} the son of Al and Marlene Avery, both teachers.Curt Sampson, [http://www.dmagazine.com/Home/2008/10/23/Sean_Avery_Dressed_to_Kill.aspx “Sean Avery: Dressed to Kill”], ''[[D Magazine]]'', November 2008. He grew up in [[Pickering, Ontario]],John Dellapina, [http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/hockey/rangers/sean-avery-stand-toronto-article-1.276721 “Sean Avery: Can’t stand Toronto,”] ''[[New York Daily News]]'', December 27, 2007. where he attended [[Dunbarton High School]].{{Cite web|url = http://www.faceoff.com/story.html?id=e5d6af76-c157-453b-8942-68d054411bf8&k=83328&add_feed_url=http://www.faceoff.com/news.atom|title = Avery disillusioned with Toronto hockey talk|date = December 6, 2007|accessdate = October 6, 2015|website = Faceoff.com|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151208094625/http://www.faceoff.com/story.html?id=e5d6af76-c157-453b-8942-68d054411bf8&k=83328&add_feed_url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.faceoff.com%2Fnews.atom|archive-date = December 8, 2015|dead-url = yes|df = mdy-all}} He has a younger brother named Scott.{{Cite web|url = http://canadafreepress.com/article/2854|title = Sean Avery’s kid brother, Scott|date = April 30, 2008|accessdate = October 6, 2015|website = Canada Free Press|last = Judi McLeod}} ==Playing career== ===Junior league (1996–2000)=== Prior to joining the NHL, Avery played for the [[Owen Sound Platers]] and the [[Kingston Frontenacs]] of the [[Ontario Hockey League]] (OHL). ===Detroit Red Wings (2001–2003)=== Avery was signed by the Detroit Red Wings as a free agent in 1999. He played one final season in the OHL before turning professional in 2000 with the [[Cincinnati Mighty Ducks]] of the [[American Hockey League]] (AHL). He broke into the NHL in the [[2001–02 Detroit Red Wings season|2001–02 season]], playing 36 games with the Red Wings and 36 in the minors. The Red Wings went on to win the [[Stanley Cup]] that season, but Avery did not play in the playoffs nor did he play the required 41 games to get his name engraved on the Cup. Midway through the [[2002–03 NHL season|2002–03 season]], Avery was traded to the [[Los Angeles Kings]] along with defenseman [[Maxim Kuznetsov]] and two draft picks for [[Mathieu Schneider]].Mike Brehm, [http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/hockey/nhl/wings/2003-03-11-schneider_x.htm “Red Wings acquire Schneider from Kings,”] ''[[USA Today]]'', March 11, 2003. He finished the season with 15 points in 51 games. ===Los Angeles Kings and NHL lockout (2003–2007)=== [[Image:seanavery.jpg|left|thumb|200px|Avery with the Kings]] In [[2003–04 NHL season|2003–04]], Avery played 76 games for the Kings, scoring 9 goals to go along with 19 assists. He also led the NHL in penalty minutes with 261. During the [[2004–05 NHL lockout]], Avery briefly played in the [[Finnish Elite League]] with the [[Lahti Pelicans]], and in the [[United Hockey League]] for the [[Motor City Mechanics]]. Along with 149 penalty minutes in just 16 games, he tallied 26 points for the Mechanics, including two hat tricks, making him the first player in Mechanics history to record two hat tricks in one season. Several players spoke publicly of their dissatisfaction with the [[NHL Players' Association]]’s leadership during the lockout, including Avery, who publicly blamed NHLPA president Bob Goodenow for wasting an entire season with a battle that alienated fans and yielded few results.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2005/07/06/avery050705.html|title=Top brass not at NHL bargaining table|work=CBC News|date=July 28, 2005}} Avery led the league in penalty minutes for the second consecutive season in 2005-06, with 257. With three games remaining, the Kings unofficially suspended Avery for the remainder of the season after he refused to do a drill in practice. Nevertheless, the team re-signed him to a one-year deal.Chris Foster, [http://articles.latimes.com/2006/jul/24/sports/sp-kings24 “Avery Gets One-Year Kings Deal,”] ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', July 24, 2006. During his time with the Kings, Avery has been said to have mocked Dustin Brown about his lisp. Former Kings' teammate [[Ian Laperrière]] said it "was bullying, like you might see in high school." But according to other players and coaches, Brown's lisp was not Avery's target, Brown's then girlfriend, now wife, Nicole was. Avery did not think Nicole Brown was glamorous enough to be a "girlfriend of a hockey player in Hollywood." Brown admits the bullying might have affected him in ways that he did not realize.{{cite news|url = http://prohockeytalk.nbcsports.com/2012/04/25/sean-avery-used-to-mock-dustin-brown-about-his-lisp-and-wife/|title = Sean Avery used to mock Dustin Brown about his lisp and wife|date = April 25, 2012|last = Mike Halford|work = NBC Sports}} ===New York Rangers (2007–2008)=== [[Image:AveryNYR.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Avery in 2007]] On February 5, 2007, in the middle of the 2006–07 season, Avery was traded to the New York Rangers. After joining the Rangers, he scored 20 points in 29 games to help the team complete a 17–4–6 end-of-season run to qualify for the playoffs. On March 17, Avery recorded a single-game career-high four points (one goal and three assists) against the [[Boston Bruins]] in a 7–0 victory.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores107/107076/NHL706086.htm|title=Rangers 7, Bruins 0|work=USA Today|date=April 18, 2006|accessdate=May 23, 2010}} Avery played in his first career playoff game on April 12 against the [[Atlanta Thrashers]], recording his first playoff points with a goal and an assist.[http://www.cbc.ca/sports/hockey/story/2007/04/14/rangers-atlanta.html “Avery, Shanahan give Rangers 2-0 series lead,”] [[CBC Sports]], April 14, 2007. He cut down on penalty minutes by about 65% in 2006–07 compared to seasons past. On August 1, 2007, Avery, as a restricted free agent, earned an [[arbitration]] award of $1.9 million for the [[2007–08 NHL season|2007–08 season]], which the Rangers accepted, keeping him with the team for at least another year.[http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=nhl&id=2957420 “Rangers re-sign LW Sean Avery after arbitrator awards him $1.9 million salary,”] [[ESPN]], August 1, 2007. On February 16, 2008, in a game against the [[Buffalo Sabres]], Avery scored a goal 10 seconds into the game, setting a record for fastest goal scored by a Ranger on home ice.{{cite news|url = https://sports.yahoo.com/nhl/recap?gid=2008021613|title = Avery scores twice, Rangers rout Sabres and Miller with 4 in 1st|agency = Associated Press|last = Podell|first = Ira|date = February 16, 2008|accessdate = October 6, 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20121023080048/http://sports.yahoo.com/nhl/recap?gid=2008021613|archive-date = October 23, 2012}} ===Dallas Stars (2008)=== Avery signed a four-year, $15.5 million contract with the [[Dallas Stars]] on July 2, 2008.[http://stars.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=450364 “Stars Sign Sean Avery,”] stars.nhl.com, July 2, 2008. He had been a roommate of the Stars' co-general manager [[Brett Hull]] when the two played for the Red Wings. Hull thought the Stars needed more fire and emotion on the ice, and felt Avery would fit the bill. Avery scored 3 goals in 23 games before he and the team parted ways following his six-game suspension by the NHL in December 2008, due to controversial remarks made about fellow players.Mike Heika, [http://www.cbssports.com/nhl/story/11147983 “Dallas Stars frustrated with suspended Avery's actions,”] ''[[Dallas Morning News]]'', December 3, 2008. The Stars placed Avery on waivers on February 7, 2009.[http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=nhl&id=3891428 “Stars place left winger Avery on waivers,”] ESPN, February 7, 2009.[https://www.tsn.ca/nhl/story/?id=266456&lid=sublink01&lpos=headlines_nhl;_ylt=AurPHuBcie0o6v6Jnqxv1zgLMxIF “Stars Assign Avery to Rangers’ AHL Affiliate in Hartford,”] [[The Sports Network|TSN]], February 10, 2009. ===Return to the Rangers (2009–2012)=== [[Image:SeanAvery2009.jpg|left|thumb|150px|Avery in the 2009 playoffs]] After clearing [[Waivers (NHL)|waivers]] on February 9, 2009, Avery was assigned to the [[Hartford Wolf Pack]], the Rangers' AHL affiliate, although he remained a member of the Stars organization (that season, the Stars had no AHL affiliate).[http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/news/story?id=3896515 Stars send Avery to Hartford] ESPN, February 10, 2009 On March 2, Avery was placed on re-entry waivers by Dallas, and claimed by the Rangers the following day.[http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/news/story?id=3948668 “Rangers take Avery off waivers,”] ESPN, March 3, 2009. On January 5, 2010, in a game against the Stars, his former team, Avery recorded one goal and three assists.Jeff Z. Klein, [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/07/sports/hockey/07nhl.html “Avery Comes Alive Against the Stars, His Ex-Team,”] ''[[New York Times]]'', January 6, 2010. On October 4, 2011, the Rangers waived Avery. The following day, he cleared waivers and was assigned to New York’s affiliate, the [[Connecticut Whale (AHL)|Connecticut Whale]] of the AHL.[https://www.tsn.ca/nhl/story/?id=377498 "Avery clears waivers, sent to AHL; Staal on injured list,"] TSN, October 5, 2011. On October 31, 2011, the Rangers placed Avery on 24-hour re-entry waivers. The move was done to bring him up as a replacement for the injured Mike Rupp. He cleared waivers and re-joined the Rangers for their November 5 game against the Montreal Canadiens.Larry Books, [https://nypost.com/2011/10/31/rangers-put-avery-on-re-entry-waivers/ “Rangers put Avery on re-entry waivers,”] ''[[New York Post]]'', October 31, 2011. Despite playing less than 10 minutes in all 15 games he played for the Rangers that season, he scored 3 goals. After being a healthy scratch for nine games, Avery was once again placed on waivers on December 30, 2011. Since no NHL team claimed him, he returned to the AHL's Connecticut Whale.[http://espn.go.com/new-york/nhl/story/_/id/7407681/sean-avery-clears-waivers-headed-ahl-now Sean Avery clears waivers]. espn.com (December 31, 2011). His last game played with the Whale was on January 27, 2012. He was left off the Whale's Clear Day list of players eligible to play for the remainder of the AHL season submitted on March 5, and told to no longer report to games or practices.Katie Strang, [http://espn.go.com/new-york/nhl/story/_/id/7654673/sean-avery-tenure-new-york-rangers-franchise-over “AHL’s Whale done with Sean Avery,”] ESPN, March 6, 2012. On March 12, 2012, Avery retired. He announced his retirement on ''Watch What Happens Live'' with host [[Andy Cohen (television personality)|Andy Cohen]].Larry Books, [https://nypost.com/2012/03/14/former-rangers-forward-avery-calls-it-quits/ “Former Rangers forward Avery calls it quits,”] ''New York Post'', March 14, 2012.Katie Strang, [http://espn.go.com/new-york/nhl/story/_/id/7681867/new-york-rangers-sean-avery-says-officially-retired “Sean Avery talks retirement,”] ESPN, March 13, 2012. ==Controversies== Over the course of his hockey career, Avery was involved in a number of controversies and fined by the NHL on numerous occasions. The controversy started early in his career; Red Wings general manager [[Ken Holland]] said he unloaded Avery during the 2002–03 season partly because he didn't seem to have respect for the game.Rosen, Dan; and Adam Kimelman. [http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=396369 Holland: "Avery hasn't matured"]. NHL.com, 2008-12-05. ===Leukemia comment=== In November 2007, Howard Berger a reporter for Toronto radio station [[FAN 590]] stated that an unnamed Rangers player had accused Avery of commenting about [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] player [[Jason Blake (ice hockey)|Jason Blake]]'s battle with leukemia, prior to a pre-game confrontation between Avery and Toronto's [[Darcy Tucker]].[http://www.cbssports.com/nhl/story/10470990 “Controversial incidents involving Sean Avery”], [[CBS Sports]], November 13, 2007. Avery, who denied the allegation, received an NHL-maximum $2500 fine, and Tucker received a $1000 fine.[http://www.citynews.ca/2007/11/13/did-sean-avery-make-comments-about-jason-blakes-fight-with-cancer “Did Sean Avery Make Comments About Jason Blake’s Fight With Cancer?”], ''[[CityNews]]'', November 13, 2007. ===The Avery Rule=== [[Image:Averyrule.jpg|right|thumb|Avery "screening" Brodeur]] On April 13, 2008, during game three of a first round [[2008 Stanley Cup Playoffs|playoff]] game against the [[New Jersey Devils]], Avery turned his back on the play in order to face and [[Screen (ice hockey)|screen]] Devils goaltender [[Martin Brodeur]] during a two-man advantage on the power play. He waved his hands and stick in front of Brodeur in an attempt to distract him and block his view. The puck was later cleared out of the Devils' zone but on the second Rangers offensive attack, Avery scored a power play goal. Although screening is a commonly used tactic (especially on the power play), notable in this instance was that Avery had spent the initial part of the play facing Brodeur while ignoring the puck, with his back to the play (normally, the player screening the goaltender is facing the play). The following day, the NHL issued an interpretation of the league's unsportsmanlike conduct rule to cover actions such as the one employed by Avery, which would now result in a minor penalty.{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/playoffs2008/news/story?id=3346729|title=NHL amends unsportsmanlike conduct rule in response to Avery's antics|publisher=ESPN|date=April 14, 2008|accessdate=2008-04-14}} This became known colloquially as "The Avery Rule".Allen Salkin, [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/29/fashion/29avery.html?pagewanted=all “The Demon on His Shoulder,”] ''New York Times'', March 27, 2009. Avery's tactics during that series against the Devils earned multiple power plays, and he scored in each of the first three games. His controversial yet effective antics helped lead the Rangers to a 4–1 series win. At the end of the series, Brodeur refused to shake Avery's hand. In an interview after game 5 when asked about the handshake line, Avery replied, "Fatso forgot to shake my hand".{{cite news|url=http://www.nj.com/devils/index.ssf/2009/03/sean_avery_gets_best_of_new_je.html|title=Sean Avery gets best of New Jersey Devils in New York Rangers' 3–0 victory|publisher=[[The Star-Ledger]]|date=March 30, 2009|accessdate=2010-02-15}} ===Heckling incident=== [[Image:Sean Avery rangers 2011-02-13.JPG|thumb|200px|Avery during the 2010–11 season]] On November 1, 2008, following a game with the Stars against the Boston Bruins, Avery was accused of shouting obscenities at a fan who had been heckling him during the game. A report of complaint was filed with the NHL, but no action was taken.Scott Burnside, [http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/columns/story?columnist=burnside_scott&id=3740622 “Isolated incident? No, Avery’s career has been defined by indiscretions,”] ESPN, December 3, 2008. ==="Sloppy seconds" comment=== On December 2, 2008, prior to the Stars' morning skate in preparation for a game against the [[Calgary Flames]], Avery approached the assembled reporters in the dressing room and stated, “I just want to comment on how it's become like a common thing in the NHL for guys to fall in love with my [[Sloppy seconds (sexual practice)|sloppy seconds]]. I don't know what that's about, but enjoy the game tonight.” At the time, two of Avery's ex-girlfriends were dating fellow NHL players - actress [[Elisha Cuthbert]] was dating Flames defenseman [[Dion Phaneuf]], and model [[Rachel Hunter]] was dating Kings center [[Jarret Stoll]].[http://www.cbssports.com/nhl/story/10470990 “Controversial incidents involving Sean Avery”], CBS Sports, November 13, 2007.[http://www.cbc.ca/sports/hockey/story/2008/12/05/avery-suspension-stars.html “Avery to sit 6 games for controversial remark,”] CBC Sports, December 5, 2008. Within hours, the NHL suspended Avery indefinitely for "conduct detrimental to the league or the game of hockey". His comments were met with near-unanimous condemnation by the Stars organization, fellow players, and fans alike. Stars owner [[Tom Hicks]] said that the team would have suspended Avery had the NHL not acted first.{{cite web|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=395722|title=NHL statement on Avery suspension}} Avery apologized the next day, calling his actions "inappropriate" and "a bad attempt to build excitement for the game".[http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/news/story?id=3743305 Stars LW Avery issues apology for televised comments about ex-girlfriends]. [[Associated Press]] via [[ESPN]]; 2008-12-04. On December 5, the NHL fixed Avery's suspension at six games, retroactive to the December 2 game against the Flames. He agreed to undergo anger management counseling due to what the NHL called unacceptable and antisocial behavior. [[NHL Commissioner|Commissioner]] [[Gary Bettman]] noted that both he and league disciplinarian [[Colin Campbell (ice hockey)|Colin Campbell]] had warned Avery several times before about his behaviour. On December 14, after the last game of Avery's suspension, the Stars announced that Avery would not return to the team. One factor in the Stars decision was that coach [[Dave Tippett]] and several of the players, including [[Mike Modano]] and [[Marty Turco]], let it be known they weren't willing to take him back on the team. Tippett had warned Avery not to talk to the media about his former girlfriends, and was outraged when he did so.[https://www.tsn.ca/nhl/story/?id=259679 Avery to continue counseling, will not return to Stars], TSN.ca, 2008-12-14.[http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/news/story?id=3768552 Stars: Avery will not return]. ESPN, 2008-12-14. According to [[The Sports Network|TSN]]'s [[James Duthie (sportscaster)|James Duthie]], Avery's teammates had soured on him not long after he arrived. The "sloppy seconds" incident was the last straw, and Hicks had been actively looking to cut ties with him while the suspension was underway.[[James Duthie (sportscaster)|Duthie, James]]. [http://www2.tsn.ca/columnists/james_duthie/?id=258309 Avery's teammates hope "indefinitely" means "forever"], [[The Sports Network]], 2008-12-03. ===Tortorella feud=== Prior to his second stint with the Rangers, Avery had been called out on numerous occasions by then TSN commentator and future Rangers coach [[John Tortorella]], who is noted for his no-nonsense behavior with his players and the press. After rejoining the Rangers, Avery’s relationship with Tortorella was uneasy, although in Avery's book he reports there were moments of mutual admiration. Nearly a year after Avery retired, on March 30, 2013, following the Rangers’ second consecutive shutout loss, a tweet from Avery's [[Twitter]] account said of his former coach, “Fire this CLOWN, his players hate him and wont play for his BS.”Greg Wyshynski, [https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/nhl-puck-daddy/sean-avery-had-huge-smile-over-john-tortorella-151814254.html “Sean Avery had ‘huge smile’ over John Tortorella’s firing by Rangers,”] [[Yahoo! Sports]], May 31, 2013.Larry Books, [https://nypost.com/2013/05/31/avery-i-had-huge-smile-after-finding-out-rangers-fired-tortorella/ “Avery: I had ‘huge smile’ after finding out Rangers fired Tortorella,”] ''New York Post'', May 31, 2013. On May 29, 2013, after the Rangers lost to the Bruins in the [[2013 NHL playoffs#.284.29 Boston Bruins vs. .286.29 New York Rangers|Eastern Conference semifinals]], Tortorella was fired.Katie Strang, [http://espn.go.com/new-york/nhl/story/_/id/9322234/john-tortorella-fired-new-york-rangers-head-coach “Rangers fire John Tortorella,”] ESPN, May 29, 2013. Avery told the ''[[New York Post]]'' that he “had a huge smile” on his face after finding out that Tortorella was fired, adding, “It’s not that I’m happy for myself. I’m happy for the Rangers and Ranger fans.” ==Advertising== ===Lipman Agency=== Upon his retirement from the NHL, in April 2012, Avery began working at New York City-based advertising and creative agency Lipman. Hired by founder, chairman and chief creative officer David Lipman, Avery was appointed chief strategic officer and helped develop strategies for numerous Lipman clients, including the campaign for the [[Stuart Weitzman]] line’s Spring/Summer 2013 campaign, featuring [[Kate Moss]], and [[7 For All Mankind]] jeans, which showcased Avery himself as a model. He has also handled a range of assignments for Lipman’s parent company, Revolate Holdings.Stuart Elliott, [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/14/business/media/sean-avery-is-not-the-average-ad-executive.html?_r=1& “From Madison Square Garden to Madison Avenue,”] ''New York Times'', December 13, 2012. ===Twtmob=== Avery is invested in Twtmob (pronounced “tweet mob”), which connects users with advertisers and campaigns, enabling users to monetize [[Twitter]], [[Facebook]] and other social media sites.Christian Red, [http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/hockey/rangers/avery-pulling-hank-torts-article-1.1346409 “Sean Avery, happy in his second career, rooting for Henrik Lundqvist, NY Rangers and even John Tortorella,”] ''[[New York Daily News]]'', May 16, 2013. ==Fashion== ===''Vogue''=== In April 2008, it was announced that Avery would be spending the summer offseason interning at ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' magazine.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwd.com/memopad/article/124369|title=Memo Pad: And his qualifications are?... Eye of the beholder...|author=Luisa Zargani, Stephanie D. Smith and Amy Wicks|date=April 25, 2008|accessdate=2009-03-03| publisher=WWD.Com}} In June 2008, Avery guest-edited Mensvogue.com, the website for ''[[Men's Vogue]]'' magazine.[http://nymag.com/thecut/2008/06/the_diary_of_vogue_intern_sean.html “The Diary of ‘Vogue’ intern Sean Avery,”] [[New York Magazine#Digital expansion and blogs|The Cut]], June 23, 2008. His interest mainly resides with women's fashion; of men's fashion Avery has said, “You do suits and pants and that's about that. Women's clothes tell a story. That's what's interesting to me.”[http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2008/10/24/clothes-make-the-ice-man.html “Clothes Make The Ice Man,”] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014214436/http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2008/10/24/clothes-make-the-ice-man.html |date=October 14, 2012 }} ''[[Newsweek]]'', October 24, 2008. In 2008, [[New Line Cinema]] put into development a film based on Avery’s life, focusing on his status as a professional athlete with an active interest in fashion, including a summer internship at ''Vogue''. [[Stan Chervin]], who was nominated for an [[Academy Award]] for Best Adapted Screenplay for ''[[Moneyball (film)|Moneyball]]'' (2011), was hired to write the script.Amy Odell, [http://nymag.com/thecut/2008/09/sean_averys_vogue_internship_t.html “Sean Avery’s ‘Vogue’ Internship to Become a Movie,”] The Cut, September 9, 2008. ===Commonwealth Utilities=== In 2009, Avery worked with men's fashion label [[Commonwealth Utilities]] to present a clothing line for [[Fashion Week]] in New York City.{{cite news|url= http://slapshot.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/09/10/its-fashion-week|title=It's Fashion Week!|work=The New York Times|date=September 10, 2009|accessdate=2009-09-11}} ==Modeling== ===Hickey Freeman=== Avery was hired to be the face of [[Hickey Freeman]]'s Spring/Summer 2012 ad campaign, shot by [[Francesco Carrozzini]]. The print ads have appeared in ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', ''DC Modern Luxury'' and other magazines. One ad featured a racy and scantily-clad Avery with a female model, while the others offered city scenes of Avery in plaid suits sporting sunglasses.Heather Zeller, [http://blog.aglamslam.com/2012/02/12/sean-averys-new-fashion-gigs-hickey-freeman-model-project-runway-guest-judge/ "Sean Avery's New Fashion Gigs: Hickey Freeman Model, Project Runway Guest Judge,"] A Glam Slam, February 12, 2013.Matthew Lynch, [http://www.wwd.com/menswear-news/lifestyle/sean-avery-in-the-neutral-zone-5698335?full=true “Sean Avery in the Neutral Zone,”] ''[[Women's Wear Daily]]'', February 16, 2012. ===7 For All Mankind=== Avery stars in the 2013 campaign for [[7 For All Mankind]], ''A Beautiful Odyssey'', a trio of shorts directed by [[James Franco]]. The films explore themes of love and passion through their portrayal of a white wedding on a California beach at sunset, with a potential love triangle looming. Avery also appears in the print ads.Lauren Levinson, [http://www.elle.com/news/fashion-style/7fam-video-james-franco-sean-avery “Exclusive: Watch James Franco’s Latest 7 For All Mankind Video Starring Sean Avery,”] ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]'', March 20, 2013. ==Film and television appearances== Avery played a small role in the 2005 [[Maurice Richard]] biopic ''[[Maurice Richard (film)|The Rocket: The Legend of Rocket Richard]]'', portraying former New York Rangers defenseman [[Bob Dill]]. Avery appeared in a 2007 episode of [[MADtv]] with Kings teammates [[Tom Kostopoulos]] and [[Scott Thornton (ice hockey)|Scott Thornton]]. He was a guest on a 2009 episode of ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]''; a Top Ten List presenter on a 2009 episode of ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]''; a guest judge on ''[[Project Runway: All Stars]]'' in 2012; and appeared on ''[[Fashion Police]]'' in 2013.[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1936239/ Sean Avery,] [[IMDb]]. Accessed September 8, 2013. He was on ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine’s Sexiest Man Alive 2007 list.[http://www.people.com/people/package/video/0,,20154290_20154496_20159873,00.html “Sexiest Man Alive 2007,”] ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'', 2007. On March 4, 2014, he was announced as one of the celebrities who will take part in the [[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. season 18)|18th season]] of ''[[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]''.Kristin Dos Santos, [http://www.eonline.com/news/517094/dancing-with-the-stars-cast-revealed-cody-simpson-nene-leakes-and-james-maslow-are-among-the-names-see-the-full-list "Dancing With the Stars Cast Revealed! Cody Simpson, Nene Leakes and James Maslow Are Among the Names—See the Full List!"] [[E! Online]], March 4, 2014. He partnered with [[Karina Smirnoff]]. The two were the second couple to be eliminated on week 2 after a double elimination. Avery is mentioned in the bestselling book ''[[Odd Man Rush: A Harvard Kid's Hockey Odyssey from Central Park to Somewhere in Sweden—with Stops along the Way]]'' by [[Bill Keenan]]. ==Book== Avery's memoir, ''Ice Capades: A Memoir of Fast Living and Tough Hockey'' (titled ''Offside: My Life Crossing the Line'' in Canada), was published by [[Blue Rider Press]] on October 24, 2017.Jack Dickey, [https://www.si.com/nhl/2017/10/24/sean-avery-book-review-ice-capades "Sean Avery Falls Short of Fearless Truth-Teller Reputation in 'Ice Capades',"] ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', October 24, 2017. He personally narrates the book on [[Audible (store)|Audible]], [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]]'s streaming book service. ==Restaurants== ===Warren 77=== In the summer of 2009, Avery opened Warren 77, a sports bar named after its address in [[Manhattan]]’s [[Tribeca]] neighborhood at 77 Warren Street. On opening night, many figures from the hockey world were present, including [[Brendan Shanahan]], [[Ken Daneyko]] and [[Henrik Lundqvist]]. The décor was meant to reflect an old New York style, with [[Andy Warhol]] originals and pictures of icons on the walls, as well as pictures of the New York Rangers, past and present. Matt Abramcyk, a former art dealer, and Chris Miller, co-owner of the Beatrice Hotel, are co-owners of the bar.Dana Mathews, [http://www.vogue.com/vogue-daily/article/vd-interview-sean-avery-on-warren-77/#1 “Interview: Sean Avery on Warren 77,”] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111021134741/http://www.vogue.com/vogue-daily/article/vd-interview-sean-avery-on-warren-77/#1 |date=October 21, 2011 }} ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'', June 1, 2009.Andrea Thompson, [http://www.newyorker.com/arts/reviews/tables/2009/09/28/090928gota_GOAT_tables_thompson “Tables for Two: Warren 77,”] ''[[The New Yorker]]'', September 28, 2009. ===Tiny's and the Bar Upstairs=== In May 2011, two years after opening Warren 77 with Abramcyk, Avery opened Tiny's and the Bar Upstairs, also in Tribeca. This would be Avery's second restaurant venture alongside Abramcyk and Rangers goalie Lundqvist. Avery handled day-to-day operations, including occasionally bussing tables.Lisa Fickenscher, Matthew Flamm and Adrianne Pasquarelli, [http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20110501/SUB/305019976 “Two Rangers’ new eatery Tiny’s breaks the ice”], ''[[Crain's New York Business]]'', May 1, 2011. In August 2013, the ''[[New York Post]]'' reported that Avery had sold his interests in both Warren 77 and Tiny's.[http://pagesix.com/2013/08/31/exiting-eateries/ “Exiting eateries,”] ''New York Post'', August 31, 2013. ==Activism== ===Marriage equality=== In May 2011, Avery recorded a video for the [[Human Rights Campaign|New Yorkers for Marriage Equality]] campaign, in support of [[same-sex marriage]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qGGH3M9NKBI|title=Sean Avery for HRC's NYers 4 Marriage Equality|publisher=YouTube|date=May 5, 2011|accessdate=2011-08-05}} Avery was believed to be the first athlete in New York to publicly voice his support for same-sex marriage. In an interview with the ''[[New York Times]]'', he stated, "I certainly have been surrounded by the gay community. And living in New York and when you live in L.A., you certainly have a lot of gay friends."John Branch, [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/08/sports/hockey/08avery.html “In Rarity, a Player Speaks Out for Gay Rights,”] ''New York Times'', May 7, 2011. Avery also traveled to [[Albany, New York]], to lobby politicians prior to the July 2011 legalization of [[Same-sex marriage in New York|same-sex marriage in New York State]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ontopmag.com/article.aspx?id=8979&MediaType=1&Category=22 |title=Cynthia Nixon Says We're at a Turning Point For Gay Marriage |publisher=Ontopmag.com |date=July 20, 2011 |accessdate=2011-11-01}}Michael Barbaro, [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/25/nyregion/after-long-wait-same-sex-couples-marry-in-new-york.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 “After Long Wait, Same-Sex Couples Marry in New York,”] ''New York Times'', July 24, 2011. ===Athlete Ally=== In May 2012, Avery joined the board of directors of [[Athlete Ally]], a nonprofit organization focused on ending homophobia and transphobia in sports by educating those in the athletic community and empowering them to take a stand against prejudice. Athlete Ally also provides public awareness campaigns, educational programming, and tools and resources to foster inclusive sports communities around the country.[http://www.athleteally.org/news/former-new-york-ranger-sean-avery-joins-athlete-ally-board/ “Former New York Ranger Sean Avery Joins Athlete Ally Board,”] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304075133/http://www.athleteally.org/news/former-new-york-ranger-sean-avery-joins-athlete-ally-board/ |date=March 4, 2014 }} [[Athlete Ally]], May 30, 2012. ==Personal life== Avery married model [[Hilary Rhoda]] at the [[Parrish Art Museum]] in New York on October 10, 2015.[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/11/fashion/weddings/hilary-rhoda-and-sean-avery-marry.html?src=me&_r=0 Marx, Linda. "Hilary Rhoda and Sean Avery Marry," ''The New York Times'', Sunday, October 11, 2015.] The couple had been engaged since November 8, 2013.Stephanie Webber, [http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/sean-avery-former-nhl-player-engaged-to-model-hilary-rhoda-20131311 "Sean Avery, Former NHL Player, Engaged to Model Hilary Rhoda,"] ''[[Us Weekly]]'', November 13, 2013. Host of The Sean Kim Show
Columnist on [[Inc. (magazine)|Inc. Magazine]] | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | mother = | father = | relatives = | family = | callsign = | awards = | website = {{URL|https://thegrowthlist.com}} | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Sean Kim''' ({{Korean|김세훈}}) is a Korean-Canadian [[entrepreneur]], investor, and podcast host.{{cite web | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tomaslaurinavicius/2018/02/06/this-college-dropout-wants-to-redefine-the-way-we-learn-foreign-languages/2/#281a127befd2 | title=This College Dropout Wants to Redefine the Way We Learn Foreign Languages | publisher=Forbes | date=8 February 2018 | accessdate=21 March 2018 | author=Laurinavicius Tomas}} He was born in [[South Korea]] and grew up in [[Vancouver]], [[Canada]], before attending [[McGill University]] in [[Montreal]]. Kim is a Columnist on Inc. Magazine, and is a contributing writer on media publications including [[TIME]], [[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]], [[Huffington Post]], and [[New York Observer]].{{cite web |url= http://inc.com/author/sean-kim |title= Sean Kim - Inc. Magazine |accessdate= 21 March 2018}}{{cite web |url= https://thenextweb.com/author/seankim/ |title= Sean Kim - The Next Web |accessdate=21 March 2018}}{{cite web |url= http://observer.com/author/sean-kim/ |title= Sean Kim {{!}} Observer |accessdate=21 March 2018}}{{cite web | url= https://www.fastcompany.com/3051781/try-these-5-steps-for-learning-new-skills-faster |title= Try These 5 Steps for Learning New Skills Faster |publisher= Fast Company |date=2 October 2015 |accessdate= 21 March 2018 | author= Kim Sean}} Through his podcast, The Sean Kim Show, he has interviewed authors, business leaders, entrepreneurs, and producers such as [[Steve Aoki]], [[Robert Greene (American author)|Robert Greene]], [[Dave Asprey]], [[Amy Cuddy]], [[Galantis]], [[Charlamagne Tha God]], and [[Suzy Welch]].{{cite web | url=https://www.inc.com/sean-kim/how-steve-aoki-creates-time-to-learn-hiring-philosophy-future-technology.html | title=How This Highly-Paid, Globe-Trotting DJ Creates Time to Learn (Hint: It's All in How He Hires) | publisher=Inc. Magazine | date=1 November 2017 | accessdate=21 March 2018}}{{cite web | url=https://www.inc.com/sean-kim/how-dj-duo-galantis-became-one-of-fastest-growing-music-groups.html | title=How This Music Group Went From Unknown to 1 Billion YouTube Views in 5 Years | publisher=Inc. Magazine | accessdate=21 March 2018}}{{cite web | url=https://www.inc.com/sean-kim/robert-greene-shares-how-to-embrace-loneliness-to-do-your-best-work.html | title=How to Embrace Loneliness to Do Your Best Work | publisher=Inc. Magazine | accessdate=21 March 2018}}{{cite web | url=https://thegrowthlist.com/suzy-welch-jack-welch/ | title=Suzy Welch on Keys to Success, Jack Welch, and Choosing a Career You Love | publisher=The Growth List | accessdate=21 March 2018}} As of March 2018, he is the top 100 most followed author on [[Medium (website)|Medium.com]]{{cite web | url=https://topauthors.xyz/ | title=Top Authors - A Leaderboard for Medium Authors | accessdate=21 March 2018}} ==Education== After finishing high school in Vancouver, Kim moved to [[Montreal]], [[Canada]] to attend [[McGill University]], where he studied [[Economics]] and [[Finance]]. In 2014, Kim dropped out of [[McGill University]] and lived in [[South America]] for over 18 months, including [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]], [[Medellin]], [[Colombia]], [[Lima]], [[Peru]].{{cite web | url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/sean-kim/how-i-went-from-dropping-out-of-college-to-freedom-in-two-years_b_6264140.html | title="How I Went From Dropping Out of College to Freedom in Two Years" | publisher=Huffington Post | date=5 December 2014 | accessdate=21 March 2018}}{{cite web | url=http://successfuldropout.com/entrepreneurship-can-be-learned-importance-of-experimenting-with-sean-kim/ | title=Successful Dropout | accessdate=21 March 2018}} The idea of his current company, Rype, was formed while he was traveling abroad.{{cite web | url=https://ideamensch.com/sean-kim/ | title="Sean Kim - Founder and CEO of Rype" | publisher=IdeaMensch | accessdate=21 March 2018}} ==Career== In 2013, Kim founded his first company, Needle, which was awarded the 'Outstanding Venture Award' by [[The Next 36]].{{cite web | url=https://www.nextcanada.com/entrepreneurs/the-next-36/2013/sean-kim | title=NEXT Canada | accessdate=21 March 2018}}{{cite web | url=http://business.financialpost.com/entrepreneur/fp-startups/the-next-36-venture-preview-night-new-cohort-already-light-years-ahead | title=The Next 36 venture preview night: New cohort already 'light years ahead' | publisher=The Financial Post | date=10 July 2013 | accessdate=21 March 2018 | author=Maimona Mashoka}} === Rype === In 2016, Kim founded his current company, Rype, an [[online marketplace]] providing language lessons online via a flat monthly subscription. As of December 2017, the company has had over 150,000 bookings from members since launch.{{cite web | url=https://huffingtonpost.com/entry/how-founder-of-rype-sean-kim-went-from-traveling-the_us_5a3fdf18e4b0d86c803c7298 | title=How Founder of Rype Sean Kim Went From Traveling the World to Connecting the World | publisher=Huffington Post | date=14 December 2017 | accessdate=21 March 2018 | author=Sahnoun Yassir}} === Other ventures === In 2017, Kim became a co-owner of iGOTHAM, an [[eyewear]] [[brand]] designed to improve [[sleep]] quality.{{cite web | url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/igotham-wants-to-be-the-vitamin-water-for-the-eyewear_us_5a5e4cd3e4b0d8c653bc0010 | title=iGOTHAM Wants to Be the 'Vitaminwater' for the Eyewear Industry | publisher=Huffington Post | accessdate=21 March 2018}}{{cite web | url=https://igotham.com/pages/our-story | title=Our Story - iGOTHAM | publisher=iGOTHAM | accessdate=21 March 2018}}{{cite web | url=https://matadornetwork.com/read/9-genius-product-hacks-digital-nomads/ | title=9 Genius Product Hacks for Digital Nomads | publisher=Matador Network | date=12 March 2018 | accessdate=21 March 2018}} === The Sean Kim Show === The Sean Kim Show is an audio and video [[podcast]] that focuses on a range of topics including [[entrepreneurship]], [[personal development]], lifestyle, [[investing]], and more. Kim has previously brought on authors, business leaders, entrepreneurs, and producers such as [[Steve Aoki]], [[Robert Greene (American author)|Robert Greene]], [[Dave Asprey]], and [[Amy Cuddy]].{{cite web | url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/the-sean-kim-show/id975978608?mt=2 | title=iTunes - The Sean Kim Show | publisher=Apple | accessdate=21 March 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official|https://thegrowthlist.com}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kim, Sean}} [[Category:American bloggers]] [[Category:American business theorists]] [[Category:American business writers]] [[Category:American motivational writers]] [[Category:American podcasters]] [[Category:Canadian people of Korean descent]] [[Category:American media personalities]] [[Category:Technology evangelists]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:21st-century American non-fiction writers]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} '''Soulieman Marouf''' (born August 1972) is a British businessman.
==Early life== Soulieman Marouf was born in August 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/04074792/officers |title=AL SHAHBA (UK) LIMITED - Officers (free information from Companies House) |website=Beta.companieshouse.gov.uk |date=20 September 2000 |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>
==Career== Marouf is a friend of the Syrian President, [[Bashar al-Assad]], and has been called his "London fixer".<ref name="thetimes1">{{cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/world/europe/article4107264.ece |title=Assad’s London fixer is taken off EU sanctions list |newspaper=[[The Times]] |date=3 June 2014 |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Robert Booth |author2=Luke Harding |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/mar/14/gilded-lifestyle-assad-coterie-conflict |title=Gilded lifestyle continued for Assad coterie as conflict raged in Syria | World news |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date= |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/world/assad-s-british-wife-went-on-harrods-spree-as-his-own-people-died-7573658.html |title=Assad’s British wife ‘went on Harrods spree as his own people died’ | World | News | London Evening Standard |website=Standard.co.uk |date=15 March 2012 |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>
In October 2012, his assets were frozen and he was banned from travelling in the European Union, the first UK resident to be subject to the EU sanctions against Syria.<ref name="thetimes2">{{cite news|author=Laura Pitel |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/uk/article3579943.ece |title=Soulieman Marouf, Assad’s man in London, is added to EU sanctions list |newspaper=[[The Times]] |date=25 October 2012 |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref> This ban was lifted in May 2014.<ref name="thetimes1"/><ref>{{cite web|author=The Committee Office, House of Commons |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201415/cmselect/cmeuleg/219-xvii/21916.htm |title=House of Commons - Documents considered by the Committee on 5 November 2014 - European Scrutiny Committee |website=Publications.parliament.uk |date= |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>
In April 2016, it was reported that Marouf, "owned a number of luxury flats in London held through offshore companies in tax havens, according to the [[Panama Papers]] ... at least six flats across London worth a total of £6m".<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/panama-papers-assad-fixer-soulieman-marouf-owns-luxury-london-property-via-offshore-firms-1553207 |title=Panama Papers: Assad fixer Soulieman Marouf owns luxury London property via offshore firms |website=Ibtimes.co.uk |date= |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== He lives in [[St John's Wood]], London, with his wife and children.<ref name="thetimes2"/>

The Minister of State for Steel, Shri Jitin Prasada is also seen in the picture|right|340px]] The '''Steel Consumers Council''' is a group under the [[Ministry of Steel]], chaired by the Cabinet in charge of the Department. India is the world’s third-largest producer of [[crude steel]], and the Council works with steel producers to ensure both the supply and demand of the steel industry.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibef.org/industry/steel.aspx| title=India is the world’s third-largest producer of crude steel | work=steel.ibef.org | accessdate=14 January 2016}}{{cite web | url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2015-07-07/news/64178310_1_indian-steel-iisco-steel-srtmi| title=India overtakes US as 3rd largest steel producer | work=economictimes.indiatimes.com| accessdate=14 January 2016}}{{cite web | url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/beni-promises-10-steel-units-in-uttar-pradesh-114020300706_1.html| title=Beni Prasad Verma promises 10 steel units in Uttar Pradesh | work=business-standard.com | accessdate=16 January 2016}} It also advises the [[Ministry of Steel]] and assists the [[Government of India]] on matters and policies concerning the Indian steel industry.In 2004 Alarmed by the recent rise in steel prices, the Union Steel Ministry had proposed setting up of an independent regulator to monitor and fix the prices of steel. It had also supported a demand to abolish the present 5 per cent import duty on scrap this was announced by [[Ram Vilas Paswan]] Minister in charge of [[Ministry of Steel]] at the 18th national '''Steel consumers council''' in 2004.{{cite web | url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/steel-ministry-moots-price-regulator-open-to-duty-cut-104061401047_1.html| title=18th national steel consumers council chaired by Cabinet Minister | work=business-standard.com | accessdate=17 January 2016}}{{cite news|title=24th Meeting of Steel Consumer’s Council Chaired by Steel {{sic|nolink=y|Ministy}} Of India|url=http://www.industrialnews.in/events/3197-24th-meeting-of-steel-consumer%E2%80%99s-council-chaired-by-steel-ministy-of-india.html||publisher=industrialnews.in|date=3 February 2014}}{{cite news|title=24th Meeting of Steel Consumer’s Council Circular|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=102937|date=3 February 2014}} The Council was founded in 1986.{{cite web | url=http://steel.gov.in/steel%20consumer%20council%2030.09.2014.pdf | work=steel.gov.in | title=Formation of Steel Consumers Council | accessdate=14 January 2016 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304064221/http://steel.gov.in/steel%20consumer%20council%2030.09.2014.pdf | archivedate=4 March 2016 | df=dmy-all }} Its members are nominated by the Minister of Steel & Mines. The tenure of the Council was initially fixed for two years, and it was re-constituted on 25 February 2010. The term of the present Council is up to 29 February 2012.{{cite web|url= http://steel.nic.in/act/boards.htm|title= Boards Councils Committees|work= steel.gov.in|accessdate= 14 January 2016|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160106074502/http://steel.nic.in/act/boards.htm|archivedate= 6 January 2016|df= dmy-all}}{{cite web | url=http://steel.gov.in/act/arrangement.htm | title=Steel Consumers Council | work=steel.gov.in | accessdate=14 January 2016 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304064023/http://steel.gov.in/act/arrangement.htm | archivedate=4 March 2016 | df=dmy-all }} The largest steel producer in India is [[Steel Authority of India]], a [[public sector]] company run by Government of India with an annual turnover of ₹50627 [[crore]] (US$7.6 billion) (FY 2014-15).{{cite web | url=http://www.sail.co.in/| title=Steel Authority of India Limited | work=sail.co.in| accessdate=14 January 2016}} == Public Sector companies == *[[Steel Authority of India Limited]] (SAIL) *[[Rashtriya Ispat Nigam Ltd.]] (RINL) *[[National Mineral Development Corporation]] Ltd (NMDC) *[[Kudremukh Iron Ore Company Ltd]] (KIOCL) *[[MECON Limited]] *Manganese Ore (India) Ltd (MOIL) *MSTC Limited *Hindustan Steel Works Construction Limited ''(HSCL)'' *Sponge Iron India Limited (SIIL) *Bharat Refractories Limited (BRL) *Ferro Scrap Nigam Limited (FSNL) *Bird Group of Companies ==Top steel companies of India in the Private sector== *[[Tata Steel]] *[[JSW Steel]] *[[VISA Steel]] *[[Bhushan Steel]] *[[Essar Steel]] == Cabinet Ministers chairing the Steel Consumers Council == * [[Ashoke Kumar Sen]] - 1991 * [[Ram Vilas Paswan]] - 2004-2009 * [[Virbhadra Singh]] - 28 May 2009–18 Jan 2011 * [[Beni Prasad Verma]] - July 2011 – May 2014 * [[Narendra Singh Tomar]] -26 May 2014 – present ==Steel consumer council Members nomination letter (copy)== [[File:Steel consumer council nomination letter.jpeg|thumb|Steel consumer council nomination letter (copy) to be published in [[The Gazette of India]]|right|300px]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Government of India}} {{Steel industry of India}} {{Ministry of Steel}} [[Category:Ministry of Steel (India)]] [[Category:1986 establishments in India]] [[Category:Consumer organisations based in India]]

'''Strategic enrollment management''' ['''SEM'''] is a crucial element of planning for new growth at a [[university]] or [[college]] as it concerns both academic program growth and facilities needs. {{ref|western}} SEM focuses on what is best for students' success while increasing enrollment numbers and stabilizing institutional revenues. A [[Student|student's]] success, according to an enrollment manager, is often based on the institution's graduation and retention rates. This means that students are often recruited based on the likelihood of them graduating. While this practice is acceptable for many privately run selective institutions, it is not a common practice of most public institutions such as community colleges.<ref>http://www.educationalpolicy.org/pdf/SEM%20Guide.pdf</ref> A real strategic enrollment management approach looks at the entire student cycle, from entry through graduation. {{ref|inside}}
According to Thomas Williams {{ref|williams}} [[enrollment management]] refers to the traditional task of “setting and meeting the goal of assembling a student body that comprises a predetermined and advantageous mix of students in terms of quality, number, and diversity in all its forms.” strategic enrollment management is a broader, more dynamic task that begins with an understanding of the world around us, anticipates changes, probes institutional mission and goals, modifying them if necessary, and coordinates “campus-wide efforts in such areas as marketing, student recruitment and retention, tuition pricing, financial aid, academic and career counseling, and curriculum reform.”
Often, SEM is understood to be focused on a college or university's traditional undergraduate students, and mobilized to meet the needs of the traditional college student. An additional area of SEM has been developed to apply these principles to the graduate student lifecycle: [[Graduate enrollment management|Graduate Enrollment Management (GEM)]]. SEM focuses on the unique services and facilities needs specific to the adult graduate student.
Some of the components of strategic enrollment management include: {{ref|southeast}} * Characteristics of the institution and the world around it * Institutional mission and priorities * Optimal enrollments (number, quality, diversity) * Student recruitment * Student fees and [[Student financial aid (United States)|Financial aid]] * Retention * Institutional marketing * [[Career counseling]] and development * Academic advising * Curricular and program development * Methods of program delivery * Quality of campus life and facilities
==History==
The Evolution of Strategic Enrollment Management (SEM) resulted from the work of a number of people and organizations since schools started being concerned with this area in the early 1970s. Boston College (through the work of Jack Maguire in 1976)<ref>http://www.maguireassoc.com/about/our-staff/</ref> and Northwestern University (through the work of William Ihlanfeldt)[2] began to use research and specific communication strategies to increase enrollment at their schools. The idea of research and using the data to target communication and marketing efforts resulted in positive enrollment numbers and drew several entrepreneurs into the field of managing enrollments. Jack Maguire subsequently created and named the first enrollment management model for recruitment and retention of students.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.collegeboard.com/prod_downloads/highered/pub/emr/EMR-spring-2007.pdf/|title=Recruitment & Admissions – Higher Ed Services - Education Professionals – The College Board|publisher=}}</ref>
In 1975, Stuart Weiner and Drs. Ron and Dori Ingersoll formed one of the earliest teams that addressed enrollment issues from the point of view of the total enrollment effort.<ref>http://www.enrollment-management.com/page13.php</ref> Gradually, the Ingersolls and others made enrollment efforts more effective by strategically addressing schools, data, academic offerings, and student services—and included retention in the overall effort.
In the late 1970s, the practice of Strategic Enrollment Management (SEM) was born. Since that time, organizations such as Noel-Levitz, Williams and Associates, and the American Association of Collegiate Registrars and Admissions Officers (AACRAO) have continued to refine the concept.
But it wasn’t until 1990 that AACRAO established the term, “Strategic Enrollment Management”, and started the first annual SEM conference,<ref>http://www.aacrao.org/Professional-Development/meetings/2013SEM/about.aspx</ref> specifically focused on pressing issues and effective practices in Strategic Enrollment Management. Beginning in 2009, AACRAO developed the first SEM Award of Excellence to recognize outstanding achievement and visionary leadership in Strategic Enrollment Management.<ref>http://www.aacrao.org/About-AACRAO/governance-and-leadership/leadership/awards/semaward.aspx</ref>
Dr. Bob Bontrager, Sr. Director of AACRAO Consulting and SEM Initiatives edited some of the first books on SEM:<ref>http://www.aacrao.org/professional-development/meetings/past-meetings/2012ExecSymposium/KeynoteSpeakers.aspx</ref> * ''SEM and Institutional Success: Integrating Enrollment, Finance and Student Access'' (2008) * ''Applying SEM at the Community College'' (2009)
In 2012, Dr. Ron Ingersoll and Dr. Dori Ingersoll, with Dr. Bob Bontrager, co-edited the book ''Strategic Enrollment Management: Transforming Higher Education''. This SEM compendium was published for the higher education profession by AACRAO. EMAS Pro then initiated the industry’s first monthly Strategic Enrollment Management webinar series, as a companion to the ''Strategic Enrollment Management: Transforming Higher Education'' book.<ref>http://emaspro.com/news-events/seminar-series/</ref> The Ingersolls serve as primary SEMinar session co-presenters.
In recent years, AACRAO has published additional books on SEM that include: * ''SEM in Canada: Promoting Student and Institutional Success in Canadian Colleges and Universities'' (2011) * ''Strategic Enrollment Management: Transforming Higher Educations'' (2012) * ''Handbook of Strategic Enrollment Management'' (2014) * ''SEM Core Concepts: Building Blocks for Institutional and Student Success'' (2017)
==Software==
As enrollment moved from a focus on marketing to including the whole institution, the need grew for software that offered better ways to communicate and work with students and parents. In the mid-1980s, the Ingersoll Group and Tom Williams developed the first software to effectively manage the process for students from inquiry to enrollment. This was The Enrollment Management Action System (EMAS™).
Noel-Levitz had developed Dialogue, a Telecounseling software designed for higher education. When Noel-Levitz merged with Williams Crockett, the telecounseling package was merged into EMAS to create EMAS''Plus''—a software system that addressed recruitment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.noellevitz.com/about-noel-levitz/the-history-of-noel-levitz|title=The History of Ruffalo Noel Levitz|publisher=}}</ref>
In 1998, Education Systems Inc. purchased EMAS products to add to software they developed for work with financial aid. At this point, the emphasis was still primarily on marketing and communication efforts. Education Systems, Inc. (doing business as EMAS™ Pro) expanded the original higher-education CRM software into a resource to address the total commitment of schools to manage their enrollment from a strategic point of view.<ref>http://www.emaspro.com/about-us/history</ref> Since then, a number of vendors serving Higher Education have emerged with CRM systems such as Hobsons, [[Jenzabar]], Talisma and Target X.
Student CRM by Data Harvesting is also a growing popular choice for a student recruitment solution for universities and colleges.
==Common misconceptions== According to Bontrager and Kerlin {{ref|bontrager}}, common misconceptions and sometimes barriers to implementing or moving strategic enrollment management forward within an institution are that strategic enrollment management is: * a quick fix * solely an organizational structure * an enhanced admissions and marketing operation * a financial drain on the institution * an administrative function separate from the academic plan and mission of the institution
==Notes== # {{note|western}} Western Carolina University [http://www.wcu.edu/stratplan/SEMgt/stratenrollmgt.htm Office of Institutional Research and Planning] # {{note|inside}} Inside Higher Education [http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2008/03/27/enroll Enrollment Managers Struggle With Image] # {{note|williams}} Thomas Williams, “[http://www5.semo.edu/strategicenrollmentmanagement/ Enrollment Strategies to Serve Tomorrow’s Students],” AGB Priorities, 21, spring 2003 # {{note|southeast}} South East Missouri State University [http://www5.semo.edu/strategicenrollmentmanagement/SEMDefinition.htm Strategic Enrollment Management] # {{note|bontrager}} Bob Bontrager, C. Kerlin, "Strategic Enrollment Management: Core Concepts and Strategies." November 2004. Orlando, FL: American Association of Collegiate Registrars and Admissions Officers
