{{short description|large sheet of strong, flexible, water-resistant or waterproof material}} {{Other uses|Tarp (disambiguation){{!}}Tarp}} {{pp-pc1|small=yes}} [[Image:Tarpaulin fly tent.jpg|thumb|right|An improvised tent using polytarp as a [[Fly (tent)|fly]]]] [[File:Abandoned homeless shelter Mawson Canberra.JPG|thumb|Abandoned homeless shelter using plastic tarp]] A '''tarpaulin''' ({{IPAc-en|US|ˈ|t|ɑr|p|əl|ɪ|n}} {{respell|TAR|pəl|in}},{{cite web|url=http://www.vocabulary.com/definition/tarpaulin|title=tarpaulin - Dictionary Definition|publisher=}} {{IPAc-en|UK|t|ɑr|ˈ|p|ɔː|l|ɪ|n}} {{respell|tar|PAW|lin}}),{{cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/tarpaulin|title=tarpaulin - Definition of tarpaulin in English by Oxford Dictionaries|website=Oxford Dictionaries - English}} or '''tarp''', is a large sheet of strong, flexible, water-resistant or [[waterproof]] material, often [[cloth]] such as [[canvas]] or [[polyester]] coated with [[polyurethane]], or made of [[plastic]]s such as [[polyethylene]]. In some places such as [[Australia]], and in military slang, a tarp may be known as a '''hootch'''. Tarpaulins often have reinforced [[grommet]]s at the corners and along the sides to form attachment points for [[rope]], allowing them to be tied down or suspended. Inexpensive modern tarpaulins are made from woven [[polyethylene]]; this material is so associated with tarpaulins that it has become colloquially known in some quarters as '''polytarp'''. ==Etymology== The word ''tarpaulin'' originated as a [[compound word|compound]] of the words ''tar'' and ''palling'', referring to a [[tar]]red canvas pall used to cover objects on [[ships]]. Sailors often tarred their own overclothes in the same manner as the sheets or palls. By association, [[sailors]] became known as "jack tars".[http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=tar Tar], ''[[Online Etymology Dictionary]]'' In the mid-19th century, "paulin" was used for such a cloth; here [[General Rosecrans]] tells a subordinate how to improvise a boat:
"A boat has been ordered up, but to make sure a large paulin will be sent down to you, with which, spread under a lot of wagon-beds, you will be able to make a large scow." (''War of the Rebellion: Official Records of the Union and Confederate Armies'', series 1, volume 5, page 260, November 1861)
"Two wagon beds ... were placed upon frames ... Thus constructed, they were placed upon a [[cotton duck|duck]] paulin, which was drawn up tightly around the beds and secured." (''Ibid.'', page 275)
==Uses== [[Image:WRESTLEMANIA.JPG|thumb|200px|left|A tarpaulin is used at [[WrestleMania XXIV]] (2008) to prevent rain from falling on the performers and stage equipment.]] Tarpaulins have multiple uses, including as shelter from the elements, i.e., [[wind]], [[rain]], or [[sunlight]], a [[Tent#Parts|ground sheet]]. Tarpaulins are often used during the build process to protect brickwork and masonry from weather damage.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/477290692|title=Brickwork : for CAA Construction Diploma and NVQs. Level 2|last=(Malcolm)|first=Thorpe, M.|date=2010|publisher=Newnes|others=Hodge, J. C. (John Charles)|isbn=9781856177658|location=Oxford|oclc=477290692}} Tarpaulins are also used for a [[fly (tent)|fly]] in [[camping]], a drop sheet for [[painting]], for protecting the infield of a [[baseball field]], and for protecting objects, such as unenclosed [[truck]]s, [[semi-trailer]]s or [[freight car]]s as well as [[wood pile]]s. Such was the demand for tarpaulins by the [[New South Wales Government Railways]], up until 1990, they operated their own tarpaulin factory.Johnson, Frank. ''A short History of the Tarpaulin Factory at Enfield.'' [[Australian Railway History|Australian Railway Historical Society Bulletin]]. September, 1999. pp. 343-347 It is also used on outdoor market stalls to provide some protection from the elements of nature. Tarpaulins are also used for advertisement printing, most notably for billboards. Another historical use of a tarpaulin is to cover seats in a stadium that are rarely used, are in venues oversized for a venue, or are obstructed view seats in a [[multi-purpose stadium]] or indoor arena for a certain sport. The entire third deck of the [[Oakland–Alameda County Coliseum]] is also covered in tarp for [[Oakland Athletics]] games, but is uncovered for [[Oakland Raiders]] games, while portions of the upper deck [[CenturyLink Field]] in [[Seattle]] are covered with images of the [[Seattle Sounders FC]] crest or sponsor logos in games which do not require use of that seating. Perforated tarpaulins are typically used for medium to large [[advertising]], or for protection on scaffoldings, the aim of the perforations (from 20% to 70%) is to reduce wind vulnerability. [[Image:perforated pvc tarp.jpg|thumb|right|An example of perforated tarpaulin]] Polyethylene tarpaulins have also proven to be a popular source when an inexpensive, water resistant fabric is needed. Many amateur builders of [[plywood]] [[sailboat]]s turn to polyethylene tarpaulins for making their sails, as it is inexpensive and easily worked. With the proper type of [[adhesive tape]], it is possible to make a serviceable [[polytarp sails|sail]] for a small boat with no [[sewing]]. [[File:VW T5 Doppelkabine-Pritsche-Plane Seitenansicht-links LWS3143.JPG|thumb|Truck with tarpaulin to cover cargo]] Plastic tarps are sometimes used as a building material in communities of indigenous North Americans. Tipis made with tarps are known as [[tarpees]].{{cite news |last1=Hopper |first1=Frank |title="Those Are Sacred": A First-Person Account From the Tipi Demonstration That Shut Down Traffic |url=https://www.thestranger.com/slog/2018/05/10/26161615/those-are-sacred-a-first-person-account-from-the-tipi-demonstration-that-shut-down-traffic |accessdate=16 July 2018 |newspaper=The Stranger |date=10 May 2018}} == Types == Tarpaulins can be classified based on a diversity of factors, such as material type ([[polyethylene]], [[canvas]], [[vinyl (fabric)|vinyl]], etc.), thickness, which is generally measured in [[Thousandth of an inch|mils]] or generalized into categories (such as "regular duty", "heavy duty", "super heavy duty", etc.), and [[grommet]] strength (simple vs. reinforced), among others. Tarpaulins can also be classified by size—a common determining factor for consumers in acquiring tarps—and measured in [[width]] by [[length]]. Actual tarp sizes are generally about three to five percent smaller than the advertised size. (Thus, a tarp advertised as {{cvt|20|x|20|ft}} will actually measure about {{cvt|19|x|19|ft}}.) Some other factors that may influence a purchase decision include color (often they come in blue, green, black, or silver), grommet type ([[aluminum]], [[stainless steel]], etc.), and grommet-to-grommet distance (these often run between {{cvt|18|in}} and {{cvt|5|ft}}). The [[Weaving|weave count]], a measure of tarp strength, often runs between (8 and 12 per square inch) and the greater the count, the greater its resistance against ripping in high wind conditions. Tarps may also be washable or non-washable and [[waterproof]] or non-waterproof, and [[rot-proof|mildewproof]] vs. non-mildewproof. Tarp [[flexibility]] refers to its ability to remain pliable during cold winter months; some tarps offer more flexibility than others in cold weather. Some manufacturers also advertise their tarps as "rot-proof", but this may be more a subjective than an objective measurement. ===Type of material === ==== Polyethylene ==== [[File:NationalCityPNC.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A tarp is used to identify a business.]] A [[polyethylene]] tarpaulin ("polytarp") is not a traditional fabric, but rather, a [[laminate]] of woven and sheet material. The center is loosely woven from strips of [[polyethylene]] plastic, with sheets of the same material bonded to the surface. This creates a fabric-like material that resists stretching well in all directions and is waterproof. Sheets can be either of [[low density polyethylene]] (LDPE) or [[high density polyethylene]] (HDPE). When treated against [[ultraviolet]] light, these tarpaulins can last for years exposed to the elements, but non-[[UV]] treated material will quickly become brittle and lose strength and water resistance if exposed to sunlight. ====Canvas==== [[Canvas]] tarpaulins are not 100% waterproof, though they are water resistant. Thus, while a little bit of water for a short period of time will not affect them, when there is standing water on canvas tarps, or when water cannot quickly drain away from canvas tarps, the standing water will drip through this type of tarp. ====Vinyl==== [[Polyvinyl chloride]] ("vinyl") tarpaulins are industrial-grade and intended for heavy-duty use. They are constructed of {{cvt|10|oz/sqyd|g/m2}} coated yellow vinyl. This makes it waterproof and have high [[Abrasion (mechanical)|abrasion]] resistance and tear strength. These resist oil, acid, grease and [[mildew]]. The vinyl tarp is ideal for agriculture, construction, industrial and trucks. ==== Silnylon ==== {{main|silnylon}} [[Tarp tent]]s may be made of [[silnylon]]. ===U.S. Color Scheme=== For years manufacturers have used a [[color code]] to indicate the grade of tarpaulins, but not all manufacturers follow this traditional method of grading. Following this color-coded system, blue indicates a lightweight tarp, and typically has a weave count of 8×8 and a thickness of {{cvt|0.005|-|0.006|in}}. Silver is a heavy-duty tarp and typically has a weave count of 14×14 and a thickness of {{cvt|0.011|-|0.012|in}}. Some of the more common colors in that scheme are: :{|class=wikitable !Color!!Name!!Approx. thickness |- |Blue||light-duty tarp||{{cvt|0.005|-|0.006|in}} |- |Yellow/Orange||medium-duty tarp||{{cvt|0.007|-|0.008|in}} |- |Green||medium-duty tarp||{{cvt|0.009|-|0.010|in}} |- |Silver||heavy-duty tarp||{{cvt|0.011|-|0.012|in}} |- |Brown||super-heavy-duty tarp||{{cvt|0.016|in}} |} ===Worldwide Color Scheme=== == In art and culture == {{recentism|section|date=September 2018}} {{relevance|section|date=September 2018}} Tarps have been used both within works of art, and also to conceal works of art from public view. A 2017 work called ''Tarp'' by Amy Malbeuf consists of a blue tarp with the word "tarp" written on it in glass beads. The work was created in reference to the use of tarps in improvised shelters by [[Homelessness in the San Francisco Bay Area|people who are homeless in Oakland, California]].{{cite journal |last1=Brown |first1=Brandon |title=Reality Check: Oakland’s Museum of Capitalism |journal=Art in America |date=17 July 2017 |url=https://www.artinamericamagazine.com/news-features/news/reality-check-oaklandrsquos-museum-of-capitalism/ |accessdate=16 July 2018 |quote=Some works more or less iterate the Museum’s core concept of radical denial. Alberta-based Métis artist Amy Malbeuf’s ''Tarp'' (2017), for instance, represents the fantasy the Museum asks us to assume. The work is a big blue tarpaulin on the wall, with the word tarp inscribed on it with glass beads. The wall text describes the piece in a voice from the future. It defines what a tarp 'was' in 2017, and then provides context: “In cities like Oakland, where capitalist development drove people out of homes, tarps became an important part of the improvised shelters which often appeared at the margins of urban areas.” While there is no doubt in my mind that Malbeuf made the piece in sympathy for and in solidarity with the staggering homeless population in Oakland, the fantasy risks increasing the conceptual distance between museumgoers and the displaced by making the reality of this crisis contrafactually pluperfect.}} Native American artist [[Nicholas Galanin]]'s 2018 retrospective art show ''Dear Listener'' at the [[Heard Museum]] included tarps as both elements of sculpture and as part of the gallery presentation.{{cite journal |last1=Duncan |first1=Jenna |title=Nicholas Galanin's "Dear Listener" with Curator Erin Joyce |journal=Java Magazine |date=5 June 2018 |url=http://javamagaz.com/?p=5078 |accessdate=16 July 2018 |quote=The artist and curator asked Heard Museum to drape the skylights in blue plastic tarps, not just for mood but also to pay tribute to the many uses of this inexpensive resource in Native communities. These tarps are often used to patch leaky roofs, cover damaged car windows and as temporary shelters and sheds. The blue plastic tarps are so ubiquitous, there’s even a nickname for homes made out of them – 'tarp-ees.' The blue tarps appear 'because they are readily accessible and very inexpensive. A lot of people are living below the poverty line on reservations,' Joyce explains ... 'Creation With Her Children,' is a collaboration with Galanin’s partner, artist Merritt Johnson. A blue plastic tarp peeks out as a layer of the woman’s petticoat. Her children are animals who gather at her feet, beneath the folds of her gown. In one hand she holds a mirror, and in the other she holds a knife, gazing at her reflection while carving her own face 'out of necessity.'}} The sculpture ''Creation with Her Children'', a collaboration between Galanin and Merritt Johnson, depicts Creation clothed in a gown made from a blue plastic tarp. While Creation carves her own face, her children, depicted as animals who have human hands, are gathered near her feet. According to the gallery text and the printed program, the tarp, which is "used heavily in indigenous communities," references "contemporary Indigenous life and the long standing effects of forced relocation under colonial rule."{{cite book |title=Printed program for Dear Listener: Works by Nicholas Galanin |date=2018 |quote=Creation with Her Children: In this work Galanin collaborated with artist Merritt Johnson. The two depict a female figure, Creation. Creation is shown carving her own face out of necessity. Her ensemble, a 17th-century style European gown, consists of a variety of materials — most notably a blue plastic tarp. The blue tarp — used heavily in Indigenous communities, creating protection from the elements, and even employed to build tipis known as ''tarpees'' — references contemporary Indigenous life and the long standing effects of forced relocation under colonial rule. Her children, two animals with human hands peeking out from under her skirt, do not emerge. They expose their sharp teeth — an act of self-defense from the world they would encounter should they leave the protection of their mother ... Blue Tarp Skylight: The decision to place blue plastic tarps over the skylights in the Dennis Lyon Family Crossroads Gallery was deliberate choice made by Erin Joyce, the Museum's Fine Arts Curator. No, the roof is not leaking or in need of repair, however the tarps do serve a critical function in the exhibition space. Firstly, they work to illuminate the use of blue plastic tarps in Indigenous North America as a cost-effective and readily available tool used to repair roofs, build tipis and various other applications. Secondly, it casts a luminous blue glow down into the gallery — which creates an atmospheric feeling of coolness, playing off the presence of a polar bear placed in the center of the room — but it is all artificial. It serves to create a reminder that we live in a borrowed landscape, under artificial light and in air-conditioned spaces.}} In one of the galleries housing ''Dear Listener,'' the skylights have been covered with blue tarps. The decision to do so was made by a museum curator in reference to the use of tarps in Indigenous North America as an inexpensive and widely available material used for building and repair. It also casts a blue glow on the room, and creates "a reminder that we live in a borrowed landscape, under artificial light and in air-conditioned spaces." Tarps have also been used to conceal art from public view, including statues of Confederate generals [[Robert Edward Lee (sculpture)|Robert E. Lee]] and [[Thomas Jonathan Jackson (sculpture)|Stonewall Jackson]],{{cite news |last1=Haag |first1=Matthew |title=Judge Orders Tarps Removed From Confederate Statues in Charlottesville |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/27/us/charlotesville-confederate-monuments.html |accessdate=16 July 2018 |newspaper=New York Times | date=27 February 2018}} an illegally placed bust of [[Edward Snowden]],{{cite news |last1=Brandom |first1=Russell |title=A renegade sculptor has mounted a bust of Edward Snowden in a Brooklyn park |url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/4/6/8353549/edward-snowden-sculpture-fort-greene-park-brooklyn-new-york |accessdate=16 July 2018 |newspaper=The Verge |date=6 April 2015}} a fiberglass casting couch in a Hollywood mall that took on new meaning after [[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse allegations|sexual abuse allegations against Harvey Weinstein in 2017]],{{cite news |last1=Knight |first1=Christopher |title=Hollywood & Highland censors sculpture in response to Weinstein scandal |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/la-et-cm-hollywood-highland-sculpture-censored-20171014-htmlstory.html |accessdate=16 July 2018 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times | date=14 October 2017}} and a [[Edward Cornwallis Statue|sculpture of the founder of Halifax, Nova Scotia]].{{cite news |last1=Willick |first1=Frances |title='Offensive and disgraceful': Protesters cheer as City of Halifax shrouds Cornwallis statue |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/cornwallis-statue-halifax-protest-removal-1.4206909 |accessdate=16 July 2018 |publisher=CBC |date=15 July 2017}} == See also == * [[Awning]] * [[Basha (tarpaulin)]] * [[Fly (tent)]] * [[Gym floor cover]] * [[Loue (tent)]] * [[Tent]] * [[Tarp tent]] * [[Visqueen]] * [[Tonneau cover]] == References == {{Wiktionary|tarp|tarpaulin|paulin}} {{Commons category|Tarpaulins}} {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Camping equipment]] [[Category:Textiles]] [[Category:Manufactured goods]]

A timeline of notable events relating to [[Global (company)|Global Radio]], a British media company founded in 2007.
==2000s== *'''2007''' **Global is founded by [[Ashley Tabor]], with financial backing from his father [[Michael Tabor]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Prosser|first1=David|title=The Business On... Ashley Tabor OBE, Founder and Global Group CEO, Global Radio|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/the-business-on-ashley-tabor-founder-and-global-group-ceo-global-radio-2079407.html |accessdate=22 October 2015 |work=The Independent |location= London |date=15 September 2010}}</ref> **25 June – Global purchases Chrysalis Radio for £170million, thereby acquiring the radio brands [[Heart Network|Heart]], [[Galaxy Network|Galaxy]], [[LBC 97.3|LBC]] and [[The Arrow (radio)|The Arrow]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Sarah |last=Crawley-Boevey |url=https://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/global-radio-buys-chrysalis-radio-170m/666477 |title=Global Radio buys Chrysalis Radio for £170m |publisher=Campaign Live |date=25 June 2007 |accessdate=13 May 2018}}</ref>
*'''2008''' **31 March – Global agrees to purchase rival [[GCap Media]] for £375million.<ref>{{cite news|first=Stephen |last=Brook |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/mar/31/gcapmedia.globalradio1 |title=Global Radio buys GCap Media for £375m |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=31 March 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2018}}</ref> **31 October – Global Radio officially takes control of all GCap Media and its brands, giving it ownership of [[The One Network]]. The GCap Media name is dropped at this time.
*'''2009''' **5 January – [[Chiltern Radio]], [[Hereward FM]], [[Radio Broadland]], [[Heart Cambridge|Q103]], [[Northants 96]], [[SGR Colchester]], [[SGR Ipswich]], and [[Heart 103.3|Horizon Radio]] are all rebranded as [[Heart Network|Heart]] after earlier being acquired by [[Global Radio]].<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/organgrinder/2009/jan/05/globalradio-commercialradio|title= Global Radio's Heart rebrand: what do you think?|publisher= Guardian.co.uk|date= 5 January 2009|accessdate= 1 January 2010 | location=London | first=John | last=Plunkett}}</ref> *7 April – Global sells its stake in the [[Digital One]] multiplex to transmission company [[Arqive]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/apr/07/global-radio-digital-one-arqiva Global sells Digital One to Arrive]</ref> **May – [[Orion Media]] purchases Midlands stations [[Free Radio Birmingham|BRMB]], [[Free Radio Coventry & Warwickshire|Mercia]], [[Free Radio Herefordshire & Worcestershire|Wyvern]], [[Free Radio Shropshire & Black Country|Beacon]] and [[Gem 106|Heart 106]] from [[Global Radio]] for a sale price worth £37.5 million.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://radiotoday.co.uk/2009/07/midlands-radio-sale-cleared/|title= Midlands radio sale cleared|publisher= Radio Today|date= 2 July 2009|accessdate= 9 September 2012}}</ref>
==2010s== *'''2010''' **21 June – [[Global Radio]] announces plans to reduce the number of its local [[Heart Network|Heart]] stations from 33 to 15 so-called "super stations" in a reorganisation that will lead to the loss of up to 200 full-time and freelance posts. The stations will have their own breakfast and drivetime shows, and local news bulletins, but all other output will come from London. A further two stations owned by Global will also be subsumed into the Heart network.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/jun/21/global-radio-restructure|title= Global Radio to halve number of local Heart stations|publisher= Guardian Media Group|work= The Guardian|first= John|last= Plunkett|date= 21 June 2010|accessdate= 3 September 2010}}</ref> **13 September – Global announce plans to scrap the [[Galaxy Network]] in order to create a nationwide [[Capital (radio network)|Capital FM]]. The plans will also include the closure of four further stations, with the new network going live in early 2011.<ref>{{cite news|first=Maisie |last=McCabe |url=https://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/global-radio-takes-capital-national/1028137 |title=Global Radio takes Capital national |publisher=Campaign Live |date=13 September 2010 |accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref>
*'''2011''' **3 January – [[Capital (radio network)|Capital FM]] launches as a nine-strong quasi-national network of stations. It subsumes [[Capital London]], [[The Hit Music Network]] and the [[Galaxy (radio network)|Galaxy]] network.
*'''2012''' **25 June – [[GMG Radio]] is sold to [[Global Radio]] for an undisclosed amount, thought to be around £50m. However, no structural changes will be made to either organisations until the deal has been investigated by Ofcom.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/06/global-radio-buys-gmg-radio/ |title=Global Radio purchases GMG Radio |publisher=Radio Today |date=25 June 2012 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref> Several rival radio groups express their concerns over the takeover and the effect it could have on commercial radio in the UK.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/06/radio-groups-oppose-global-domination/ |title=Radio groups oppose Global domination |publisher=Radio Today |date=25 June 2012 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref> **3 July – [[Global Radio]] announce plans to branch into television with the launch of two non-stop music channels; [[Heart TV]] and [[Capital TV]], which will go on air from September.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/07/global-radio-to-launch-heart-capital-tv/ |title=Global Radio to launch Heart & Capital TV |publisher=Radio Today |date=3 July 2012 |accessdate=9 July 2012}}</ref> **3 August – [[Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport|Culture Secretary]] [[Jeremy Hunt (politician)|Jeremy Hunt]] instructs Ofcom and the [[Office of Fair Trading]] to examine Global Radio's £70m purchase of GME Radio.<ref>{{cite news|first=Katherine |last=Rushton |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/mediatechnologyandtelecoms/media/9449285/Jeremy-Hunt-calls-on-Ofcom-and-OFT-to-probe-Guardians-radio-deal.html |title=Jeremy Hunt calls on Ofcom and OFT to probe Guardian's radio deal |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=3 August 2012 |accessdate=4 August 2012}}</ref> **11 October – The Office of Fair Trading agrees to fast-track the investigation into Global Radio's purchase of GMG Radio after Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport [[Maria Miller]] says the deal will not be investigated for media plurality. The matter is also forwarded onto the [[Competition Commission]], which oversees business mergers and takeovers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/10/the-oft-grants-fast-track-to-global-radio/ |title=The OFT grants fast-track to Global Radio |publisher=Radio Today |date=11 October 2012 |accessdate=13 October 2012}}</ref> The Competition Commission later announces 27 March 2013 as the date on which it will publish its findings into the takeover.<ref name="auto1">{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/10/date-set-for-global-radios-competition-commission-results/ |title=Date set for Global Radio's CC results |publisher=Radio Today |date=11 October 2012 |accessdate=13 October 2012}}</ref> **12 October – Global launches two television channels – [[Heart TV]] and [[Capital TV]].<ref name="RadioToday-2012-10-12">{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/10/heart-and-capital-tv-start-broadcasting/ |title=Heart and Capital TV start broadcasting |publisher=Radio Today |date=12 October 2012 |accessdate=13 October 2012}}</ref>
*'''2013''' **14 February – The [[Competition Commission]] publish their preliminary findings into the [[Global Radio]] takeover of [[GMG Radio]], recommending a full or partial sale of the now renamed Real and Smooth Radio Ltd.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2013/02/cc-offers-three-options-for-global-radio/ |title=CC offers three options for Global Radio |publisher=Radio Today |date=14 February 2013 |accessdate=14 February 2013}}</ref> **21 May – The Competition Commission publishes its final report into Global's acquisition of GMG Radio, requiring Global to sell radio stations in seven locations.<ref name=CC-2013-05-21>{{cite news|url= http://www.competition-commission.org.uk/media-centre/latest-news/2013/May/global-gmg-final-report |title=Global/GMG Final report|publisher= Competition Commission|date= 21 May 2013|archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20140402141250/http://www.competition-commission.org.uk/media-centre/latest-news/2013/May/global-gmg-final-report|archive-date=4 February 2014}}</ref>{{efn|The stations involved were: [[106.6 Smooth Radio|Smooth]] or [[Capital East Midlands|Capital]] (East Midlands); [[Real Radio Wales|Real]] or [[Capital South Wales|Capital]] (South Wales); [[Real Radio Wales|Real]] or [[Heart North West and Wales|Heart]] (North Wales); [[Capital Manchester|Capital]] or [[Real Radio XS|Real XS]] with either [[Real Radio North West|Real]] or [[Smooth Radio 100.4|Smooth]] (North West); [[Real Radio North East|Real]] or [[97.5 & 107.7 Smooth Radio|Smooth]] or [[Capital North East|Capital]] (North East); [[Real Radio Yorkshire|Real]] or [[Capital Yorkshire|Capital]] (Yorkshire); and [[Real Radio Scotland|Real]] or [[Capital Scotland|Capital]] (Scotland)<ref name=CC-2013-05-21/>}} **1 October – Smooth Radio is moved to Global Radio's Leicester Square headquarters in London and given a makeover.<ref name=RT-2013-10-03>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2013/10/global-welcomes-smooth-radio-to-london-hq/ |title=Global welcomes Smooth Radio to London HQ |publisher=Radio Today |date=3 October 2013 |accessdate=3 October 2013}}</ref> **3 October – Global Radio announces that Smooth 70s will close less than a week after Smooth programming moved to its London headquarters.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2013/10/smooth-radio-70s-to-close-after-21-months/ |title=Smooth Radio 70s to close after 21 months |publisher=Radio Today |date=3 October 2013 |accessdate=3 October 2013}}</ref> **7 October – Choice FM is rebranded as Capital Xtra and launches nationally on DAB radio.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2013/10/global-to-change-choice-to-capital-xtra/ |title=Global to change Choice to Capital XTRA |publisher=Radio Today |date=2013-10-03 |accessdate=2013-10-03}}</ref> **31 December – A financial report released by Global Radio shows the company paid £69m for the purchase of [[GMG Radio]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2013/12/globals-gmg-radio-takeover-cost-revealed/ |title=Global's GMG Radio takeover cost revealed |publisher=Radio Today |date=31 December 2013 |accessdate=1 January 2014}}</ref>
*'''2014''' **20 January – [[Global Radio]] is found to be in breach of their license remit for [[Heart Cornwall]] after a listener complained to [[OfCom]] that there was not enough local news and speech to make it a fully local station.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/01/global-radio-in-breach-for-heart-cornwall/ |title=Global Radio in breach for Heart Cornwall |publisher=Radio Today |date=20 January 2014 |accessdate=27 January 2014}}</ref> **6 February – Global Radio sells eight of its regional stations to Irish media holdings firm [[Communicorp]].<ref name=Radio-Today-2014-02-06>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/02/communicorp-buys-8-global-radio-stations/ |title=Communicorp buys 8 Global Radio stations |publisher=Radio Today |date=6 February 2014 |accessdate=6 February 2014}}</ref> **11 February – [[LBC 97.3]] launches nationally on the [[Digital One]] platform, taking over the slot formerly occupied by Jazz FM. The station also secures a sponsorship deal with the ''[[Financial Times]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/01/global-radio-to-take-lbc-national-on-d1/ |title=Global Radio to take LBC national on D1 |publisher=Radio Today |date=30 January 2014 |accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/02/financial-times-sponsors-new-uk-wide-lbc/ |title=Financial Times sponsors new UK wide LBC |publisher=Radio Today |date=11 February 2014 |accessdate=12 February 2014}}</ref> **14 March – Global Radio announces that Gold will become a non-stop music service, with the exception of the breakfast show and Saturday's ''Vinyl Heaven''. Presenters Paul Coyte, Eamonn Kelly, Dean Martin and [[Andy Peebles]] are also dropped from the network.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/03/gold-drops-presenters-outside-breakfast/ |title=Gold drops presenters outside breakfast |publisher=Radio Today |date=14 March 2014 |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> **24 March – ***Smooth Radio returns to airing local output on its regional frequencies, with local programming for Breakfast and Drivetime, and a raft of [[Smooth Radio presenter history|new presenters]] joining the network.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/03/smooth-radio-returns-to-regional-output/ |title=Smooth Radio returns to regional output |publisher=Radio Today |date=19 March 2014 |accessdate=19 March 2014}}</ref> ***Smooth Radio replaces [[Gold (radio)|Gold]] on MW across southern England.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.a516digital.com/2014/02/gold-announces-am-and-dab-departure-date.html|title=Gold announces AM and DAB departure date|publisher=|accessdate=10 May 2018}}</ref> **6 May – [[Heart North Wales]] launches. Consequently, the two local Heart north Wales stations become part of the Capital network. **September – Global launches its Make Some Noise charity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/09/global-launches-make-some-noise-charity/|title=Global launches Make Some Noise charity – RadioToday|website=Radiotoday.co.uk|accessdate=27 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180128132537/https://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/09/global-launches-make-some-noise-charity/|archivedate=28 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> **9 October – Global's first Make Some Noise Day raises over £1million for good causes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/1316672/global-makes-noise-charity-raises-1m|title=Global 'Makes Some Noise' charity raises £1m|website=Campaignlive.co.uk|accessdate=27 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170218144244/http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/1316672/global-makes-noise-charity-raises-1m|archivedate=18 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> **27 December – Global launches [[Smooth Extra]] on DAB.<ref name=Radio-Today-2014-12-27>{{cite news|first=Roy |last=Martin |url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/12/smooth-extra-launches-on-dab-digital-radio/ |title=Smooth Extra launches on DAB digital radio |publisher=Radio Today |date=27 December 2014 |accessdate=7 January 2015}}</ref>
*'''2015''' **7 September – [[Global (company)|Global]] announces that XFM will be relaunched as a national station called [[Radio X (United Kingdom)|Radio X]] on 21 September.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2015/09/full-line-up-for-globals-radio-x-confirmed/ |title=Full line-up for Global's Radio X confirmed |publisher=RadioToday |date=7 September 2015 |accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref> **13 September – Ahead of the relaunch of XFM as [[Radio X (United Kingdom)|Radio X]], Global hands back the Paisley licence, on which it had broadcast [[XFM Scotland]], to [[Ofcom]] when the regulator refused Global's request to network 24/7 from London.
*'''2016''' **18 January – Following [[Global Radio]]'s purchase of Liverpool station Juice 107.6, the station is relaunched as [[Capital Liverpool]].<ref>[http://www.thisisglobal.com/global-updates/?hp=1551#capital-liverpool-will-launch-in-january-2016 Capital Liverpool Will Launch In January 2016], Global Radio, 16 December 2015</ref> **23 February – Launch of [[Heart Extra]]. **March – [[Manchester]] station [[Real Radio XS]] is rebranded as [[XS Manchester]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Macpherson |first=Ande |url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2016/02/real-radio-xs-to-rebrand-as-xs-manchester/ |title= Real Radio XS to rebrand as XS Manchester |publisher=RadioToday |date=23 February 2016 |accessdate=16 March 2016}}</ref> **12 September – Launch of the [[Global Academy]], a [[University technical college]] based in London.
*'''2017''' **20 January – The Global Academy is officially opened by the [[William, Duke of Cambridge|Duke of Cambridge]] and [[Prince Harry]]. Two breakfast shows from the [[Global Group|Global]] brands are broadcast live from the academy, [[Heart London]] Breakfast with [[Jamie Theakston]] and [[Emma Bunton]] and [[Nick Ferrari]] on [[LBC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.global.com/global-updates/#the-duke-and-duchess-of-cambridge-and-prince-harry-to-officialy-open-the-global-academy-in-support-of-heads-together|title=Global Updates – Global|first=Global|last=Radio|website=Global.com|accessdate=27 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171227095204/http://www.global.com/global-updates/#the-duke-and-duchess-of-cambridge-and-prince-harry-to-officialy-open-the-global-academy-in-support-of-heads-together|archivedate=27 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> **14 March – Launch of [[Heart 80s]]. **20 November – [[Global (company)|Global]] announces that it has purchased Cumbrian stations [[The Bay (radio station)|The Bay]] and [[Lakeland Radio]] from [[CN Group]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://radiotoday.co.uk/2017/11/global-purchasesthe-bay-and-lakeland-radio/|title=Global purchases The Bay and Lakeland Radio|date=20 November 2017|publisher=Radio Today|accessdate=21 November 2017|work=BBC News}}</ref> **20 December – [[Global Radio]] announce details of the voting categories for its [[1st Global Awards|inaugural]] awards ceremony, the [[Global Awards]] to be held at London's [[Hammersmith Eventim Apollo]] on 1 March 2018. The Awards will be reflective of the music, programmes and news aired on its network of stations.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://radiotoday.co.uk/2017/12/global-launches-its-own-entertainment-awards/|title=Global launches its own entertainment awards|work=Radio Today|date=20 December 2017|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.musicweek.com/media/read/global-awards-categories-revealed/070947|title=Global Awards categories revealed|publisher=Music Week|date=20 December 2017|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref>
*'''2018''' **January – [[Global Radio]] announces that it has brought [[Brighton]] station [[Juice 107.2]] for an undisclosed sum.<ref>[https://radiotoday.co.uk/2018/01/global-buys-juice-107-2-in-brighton-hove/ Global buys Juice 107.2 in Brighton & Hove], RadioToday, 17 January 2018</ref> and in August it revealed that it would relaunch the station as Capital Brighton on Monday 3 September.<ref>[https://radiotoday.co.uk/2018/08/capital-brighton-to-launch-on-3rd-september/ Capital Brighton to launch on 3rd September], Tramways Company]], London Street Tramways Company, [[Corris Railway]] Company, Bell Punch Company Ltd., Hull Street Tramways Company, North Metropolitan Tramway Company and Belfast Street Tramways Company.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=M5DVAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA298&dq=walter+rathbone+bacon+trams&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB4Q6wEwAGoVChMIgefPxaSmxwIVwvceCh0pIwSc#v=onepage&q=walter%20rathbone%20bacon%20trams&f=false| Book For 1883'', 1883, pg. 345]</ref><ref> In 1882, in [[Bordeaux]], France, Bacon married [[Virginia P. Bacon|Virginia Purdy Barker]], the youngest granddaughter of business magnate, [[Cornelius Vanderbilt]].<ref>''The Standard'', Friday March 10, issue 1785 (London: 1882), p. 1. Accessed through ''19th Century British Library Newspapers Part II''</ref> Bacon and his wife spent most of their time abroad, particularly in London and at Netherdale Estate, their Manor house in [[Turriff]], Scotland. However, after the outbreak of [[World War I]] travel to Europe became more difficult and the Bacons remained in New York.<ref name="jstor.org">[https://www.jstor.org/stable/25589459?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents ''American Art News'', April 12, 1919]</ref><ref name="jstor.org"/><ref>{{cite book|title=Social Register, Summer ...: Contains the Summer Addresses of Residents of New York, Washington, Philadelphia, Chicago, Boston and Baltimore|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ffZBAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA15|year=1913|publisher=Social Register Association|page=15}}</ref>
Walter, with his brother [[Edward R. Bacon]], a lawyer, acted as president of the Knickerbocker Apartments at 247 Fifth Avenue, where the two lived with Walter's wife.<ref>[http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1917/11/15/102650638.html?pageNumber=13 ''New York Times'' November 15, 1917]</ref><ref>[https://archive.org/stream/ldpd_5767518_000#page/n23/mode/2up| ''The Elite of New York, Society List and Club' Register'', New York, 1915, pg. 17</ref> The Knickerbocker apartments, in William B. Duncan's former mansion, were sold to the newly formed gentlemen's club, the [[Knickerbocker Club]]. The Knickerbocker club was formed out of the [[Union Club of the City of New York]], by a group of members exasperated with the admittance of younger, less traditional members.<ref>[http://daytoninmanhattan.blogspot.com/2012/09/the-lost-1882-knickerbocker-apartments.html Tom Miller, ''The Lost 1882 Knickerbocker Apartments'', September 3, 2012]</ref> Walter was also a member of [[Racquet and Tennis Club]], in New York and The [[Reform Club]], in London.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZJVYAAAAMAAJ&q=walter+rathbone+bacon+reform+club&dq=walter+rathbone+bacon+reform+club&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCcQ6wEwAGoVChMI4YKinK-mxwIVAVc-Ch22GQDk| D. K. MacDowell, ''Commodore Vanderbilt and his Family: A Biographical Account of the Descendants of Cornelius and Sophia Johnson Vanderbilt'', 1989, pg. 69]</ref>
Walter died in his Fifth Avenue apartment on November 14th, 1917.<ref>[http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1917/11/15/102650638.html?pageNumber=13 ''New York Times'' November 15, 1917]</ref> In 1911, Virginia established the Walter Rathbone Bacon Fellowship at the Smithsonian Institution in memory of her husband.<ref>http://www.smithsonianofi.com/walter-rathbone-bacon-fellowship/</ref>
